column12: ASSEMBLY FIXTURE FOR FIXED POINT PROBE CARD
column13: A fixture for assembling a probe card adapted to test integrated circuit patterns having contacts deployed thereon. The card includes an opening providing access to a pattern and a ring of spaced conductive pads surrounding the opening. Anchored on selected pads are blade-like needle-holders having needles extending therefrom to engage the contacts in the pattern being tested. The fixture is designed to facilitate attachment of each needle-holder blade to its pad on the card and to orient the blade before such attachment so that the needle point is precisely aligned with the related contact.

column12: Improvements in or relating to travelling wave tubes
column13: 809,951. Backward-wave tubes. STANDARD TELEPHONES & CABLES Ltd. March 20, 1957, No. 9093/57. Class 39(1). A hairpin interdigital line for a backward wave oscillator tube has the sets of U-shaped metal ribbon conductors, or hairpins 14, 14<SP>1</SP> held between the middle members 12, 12<SP>1</SP> and pairs of outer members 9, 10 and 91, 101 respectively of the bounding walls. The outer members have slots to receive the limbs of the conductors. The wall members and the conductors are gold plated and bonded together by a gold diffusion process, or brazed with suitable solder. At one end the conductors are of resistive material, or coated with such material, to provide a wave absorbing termination. The conductors may be curved instead of, flattened at the base of the U. The complete structure includes side plates 16, 17.

column12: Mechanism for extending and positioning a high-lift device relative to a wing
column13: The invention makes available an operating and positioning arrangement for slats on the leading edges of wings, wherein a slat panel is connected to one end of an extendable guide rail part which is held and guided at its other end by means of rollers which are mounted on a fixed structure in the leading-edge section of the wing. The operating and positioning arrangement comprises a drive and programming mechanism which is integral or is constructed to form a unit, is connected to the slat panel and operates in such a manner that it combines the opening or closing process of an aerodynamic slot with a slat extending drive mechanism. The drive and programming mechanism, which is integral or is combined to form a unit comprises a contoured cam guide track which has the approximate shape of an S-cam guide track and has a roller follower which is connected to an element and a drive arm; and this combination permits synchronisation of the slat operation with the programming control of the slat deflection angle and the opening and closing of an aerodynamic slot.

column12: Wing leading edge slat actuating and positioning mechanism
column13: The wing leading edge slat actuation and positioning mechanism system is provided so that a slat panel can be connected to one end of an extensible track which is supported and guided at its other end by rollers mounted to fixed structure in the leading edge section of the wing. The actuation and positioning system comprises a unified drive and a programming mechanism which is connected to the slat panel and functions to combine an aerodynamic slot opening or closure operation with a slat extension drive mechanism. The unified drive and programming mechanism comprises a contoured cam track in the shape of an S and having a roller follower which is connected to a link and drive arm. This combination allows synchronisation of slat actuation with programming control of slat angle-of-deflection and aerodynamic slot opening or closure.

column12: TEST PROBE ASSEMBLY FOR IC CHIPS

column13: A wing leading edge slat actuation and positioning system, wherein a slat panel is connected to one end of an extensible track member which is supported and guided at its other end, by rollers mounted to fixed structure in the leading edge section of the wing. The actuation and positioning system comprises a unified drive and a programming mechanism which is connected to the slat panel and functions to combine an aerodynamic slot opening or closure operation with a slat extension drive mechanism. The unified drive and programming mechanism comprises a contoured camtrack somewhat in the shape of an S-camtrack and having a roller follower which is connected to a link and drive arm; and this combination allows synchronization of slat actuation with programming control of slat angle-of-deflection and aerodynamic slot opening or closure.

column12: TEST PROBE ASSEMBLY FOR IC CHIPS
Probes for fixed point probe cards
column13: Probes for a probe card adapted to test integrated circuit patterns having contacts deployed thereon, the card including an opening providing access to a pattern and a ring of spaced conductive pads surrounding the opening. The probes are adapted to be anchored on selected pads of the card, each probe being constituted by a rigid, blade-like needle-holder having a deflectable needle extending therefrom to engage a respective contact in the pattern being tested.

column12: MECCANISMO ESTENSORE RETRATTORE PER FEZIONATO PER IPERSOSTENTATORI SISTEMATI SUL BORDO D ATTACCO DELLE ALI DI UN AEROPLANO
Multi-level test probe assembly for IC chips
column13: A multi-level test probe assembly for checking an integrated circuit chip before terminal leads are applied to the contact pads thereof which are deployed on the chip on a common plane, some pads being inwardly displaced relative to other pads. The assembly includes a planar insulation card provided with a port and having a printed circuit thereon whose traces are connected to a plurality of test terminals connectable to external testing equipment. Surrounding the port and bonded to the card is a mounting ring of dielectric material having a flat face on which is supported a first radial array of fine wires lying in a horizontal plane, the trailing end of each wire being connected to a respective trace. The wires cantilever across the port and converge toward the central region thereof below which is disposed the chip to be tested, the tapered leading end of each wire being double bent to define a needle having a shank section and a tip section terminating in a tip which engages a respective contact pad on the chip. Overlying the first layer and bonded thereto is a second layer of dielectric material having embedded therein a second radial array of fine wires whose tips engage those contact pads on the chip not engaged by the first array.

column13: A wing leading edge slat actuation and positioning system, wherein a slat panel 31 is connected to one end of an extensible track member 24 which is supported and guided at its other end, by rollers 43 mounted to fixed structure in the leading edge section of the wing. The actuation and positioning system comprises a unified drive and a programming mechanism which is connected to the slat panel and functions to combine an aerodynamic slot opening or closure operation with a slat extension drive mechanism. The unified drive and programming mechanism comprises a contoured camtrack 33 somewhat in the shape of an S-camtrack and having a roller follower 39A which is connected to a link 38 and drive arm 35; and this combination allows synchronization of slat actuation with programming control of slat angle-of-deflection and aerodynamic slot opening or closure. In a take-off setting (Fig. 3, not shown) the slat forms a smooth continuous surface with the wing upper surface, while the landing setting shown opens a slot 27. <IMAGE>

column12: Test probe assembly for IC chips.
column13: A test probe assembly for checking an integrated circuit chip before terminal leads are applied to the contacts thereof which are deployed on the chip in a common plane. The assembly includes a planar insulation card (T 10 ) provided with a port (T 11 ) and having a printed circuit thereon whose traces are connected to a plurality of test terminals (T 16 ) connectable to external testing equipment. Surrounding the port (T 11 ) and bonded to the card is a mounting ring of dielectric material having a flat face on which is supported a radial array of fine wires (T 17 ). These are maintained in their assigned positions by a layer of dielectric material adherent to the face, the wires (T 12 ) being embedded in the layer. The wires (T 12 ) cantilever across the port (T 11 ) and converge toward the central region thereof below which is disposed the chip (T 20 ) to be tested, the leading ends of the wires (T 12 ) being double bent to define obtuse angle needles whose tips engage the respective contacts on the chip (T 20 ). The trailing ends of the wire (T 12 ) which diverge outwardly from the ring are soldered to the traces whereby each needle is connected to a respective test terminal (T 16 ).

column12: Test probe assembly for IC chips
column13: A test probe assembly for checking an integrated circuit chip before terminal leads are applied to the contacts thereof which are deployed on the chip in a common plane. The assembly includes a planar insulation card provided with a port and having a printed circuit thereon whose traces are connected to a plurality of test terminals connectable to external testing equipment. Surrounding the port and bonded to the card is a mounting ring of dielectric material having a flat face on which is supported a radial array of fine wires lying in a horizontal plane. These are maintained in their assigned positions by a layer of dielectric material adherent to the face, the wires being embedded in the layer. The wires cantilever across the port and converge toward the central region thereof below which is disposed the chip to be tested, the tapered leading end of each wire being double bent to define a needle having a shank section and a tip section terminating in a tip which engages a respective contact on the chip. The tip section has a downward slope whereby the tips of the needles are exposed to view through a microscope for purposes of alignment. The trailing end of each wire is soldered to a respective trace connecting each needle to a test terminal.

column12: Perfectionnements apportés aux machines à imprimer
Flag pole mounted unfurling device and associated baton
column13: A flag pole mounted unfurling device is installed on a flagpole and rotates to minimize the unwanted furling of the flag. The device includes a lower swivel, an upper swivel, and a baton that extends between the lower swivel and the upper swivel to retain the two swivels in alignment and properly separated. The upper swivel and lower swivel are free to rotate around the axis of the pole while the baton serves to couple the upper and lower swivels together, both rotationally and longitudinally. The entire assembly is longitudinally retained on the pole by an upper collar and a lower collar and minimizes the unwanted furling of a flag through ‘dynamic instability.’

column12: New or improved means for feeding work-pieces to presses and like machines
column13: 724,085. Metal-working presses. PRESS GUARDS, Ltd. April 28, 1952 [April 28, 1951], No. 10011/51. Class 83 (4). Means for feeding individual work-pieces to a press &c. comprises an arm 68 which can be oscillated between limits about a vertical axis and moved angularly about a horizontal axis to raise and lower work-gripping means 69 on the arm, the movement of the arm being synchronized with the operation of the machine by an oscillating disc 31 coupled to a member 20 adapted to be mounted on a continuously rotating part of the machine. The press tools 16, 19 are operated by a fly-wheel 10 and crank 13, which also reciprocate an adjustable rod 23 through the disc 20. The rod 23 oscillates the disc 31 through 90 degrees which in turn, through a rod 40, oscillates a block 35 between the adjustable limit stops 50. The block 35 oscillates on a block 34 which is itself oscillated about the horizontal axis by a cam 60 on the disc 31 and a rod 55. The block 35 carries the work-gripping fingers 69, which are operated by a wedge 71 and an air cylinder 7 2 controlled by a valve actuated by a cam on the disc 31. In operation, the block 35 is oscillated to bring the fingers over a blank on a table 76, the block 34 is then moved angularly and the fingers closed to grip the blank. The arm returns and deposits the blank on to the bottom tool 16 as the ram reaches its upper position. For picking up sheets 81, Fig. 6, the fingers 69 may be replaced by a suction cup 80. The sheets are separated prior to lifting by an air-jet 84. Alternatively, an electromagnet or a permanent magnet and pneumatic releasing means may be used. The blanks may be supplied to a pick-up position by a magazine 90 and a pneumatically-actuated pusher, or by a stack automatically raised by a screwed spindle, or by a rotary table loaded by the operator and fed step-by-step by an airoperated ratchet device. Jets 98 actuated by cams 100 on the disc 20 remove swarf and discharge the work-pieces from the tools.

column13: 2243. Evans, A. F. Feb. 4. Gas or explosive-vapour engines.-Liquid fuel and a small quantity of air are injected into the combustion chamber a<2>, through the inlet passage d3, by a piston pump d to which is connected a piston c, working in a chamber open to the cylinder inlet and exhaust port a<3>, through a communicating- pipe b<1>. Towards the end of the up-stroke ef the pistons c, d, which is effected by a spring c<1>, liquid fuel is drawn into the chamber d', through the inlet pipe e<1> and nozzle e<3>, by a current of air entering the vacuous space below the piston d through the valve e' and the governor-controlled valve e<5>. On the down-stroke, the fuel and air are forced into the combustion chamber through a camactuated valve d<2> by air forced into the chamber b during the compression stroke of the working piston. The invention has for its object the use of heavy oils, and solid fuel may be used if liquefied before reaching the nozzle e3.

column12: An Improvement in Lithographic Printing Machines

Lithographic and like printing.-In machines in which the printing pressure between two cylinders, or between a cylinder and a plane surface, is exerted in a direction considerably removed from the vertical, the bearings of the cylinder or cylinders are mounted on runners, rollers, or balls, to reduce friction in the movements of the bearings. Fig. 1 shows a rotary machine having two cylinders a, b pressed together by springs f, and Fig. 2 shows a machine with an impression cylinder a pressed against the forme b<1> by the springsf. column12: New or improved means for controlling the working of strip material
column13: 795,245. Feeding webs. PRESS EQUIPMENT, Ltd. April 20, 1956 [April 21, 1955], No. 11482/55. Class 100(1) [Also in Group XXII] In an arrangement for feeding strip 11 to a punching or shearing press which cuts off lengths of the strip, the feeding mechanism 12 feeds the strip against a stop 16 so forming a bow 17, and a detecting device 18 is actuated when the bow 17 reaches a predetermined height to stop or slow the feeding mechanism 12 and to initiate a further operation, such as the working stroke of the press which may be mechanical or hydraulic. When a length of the strip has been cut off the bow 17 collapses and the feeding mechanism, e.g. rollers, is started or speeded up until the bow again actuates the detecting device which may be an electric switch or a photoelectric device. The detecting device may disconnect the drive of the feeding mechanism and actuate a brake. Specification 780,861 [Group XXII] is referred to.

A stacker-reclaimer has a luffing and slewing mounting (2, 4) supporting a boom structure with a main, forwardly extending boom (14) having material-conveying means running along it, and a rearwardly extending tail boom (22) with a counterbalance weight (34) depending from its rear end. The tail boom is at a higher level than the main boom to provide clearance of a feeder conveyor (26) to the material-conveying means. The counterbalance weight is attached by a pivot (30) on the tail boom and is displaceable about the pivot by a control cable (36) attached to a non-luffing part (40) of the luffing and slewing mounting forwards of the luffing axis (6) whereby the weight is displaced forwards in relation to the pivot in upward luffing movements of the boom structure. This compensates for the rearward displacement of the rear end of the tail boom in such movements, and reduces the maximum overturning moment to be resisted in the working luffing range.

column12: Flexible membrane discharge for vacuum hopper
column13: A vacuum storage hopper for storing and dispensing granular materials, including a storage chamber having a lower inverted conical discharge section terminating in a discharge valve. At least one material inlet and a combination air inlet-outlet are connected to the upper part of the storage chamber. A source of air under vacuum and pressure is connected to the air inlet-outlet for exhausting air from the storage chamber to draw granular material thereinto, and for supplying air under pressure to the storage chamber to assist the discharge of granular material from the hopper. A flexible, resilient air-impervious membrane of inverted generally conical configuration is located in the discharge section of the hopper; the membrane has its upper edge secured to the upper edge of the discharge section of the hopper and hangs downwardly therefrom. A short strip of the membrane, no more than a minor fraction of its circumference, is secured to the storage chamber below its upper edge. A port in the discharge section of the storage chamber is used to introduce air under pressure between the wall of the storage chamber and the membrane at a point above the strip of membrane and below its upper edge.

column12: Improved Distribution Valve for Internal Combustion Motors.
column13: 15,841. Evans, A. F. July 9, 1912, [Convention date]. Starting.-A valve for distributing compressed air for starting in either direction comprises a ported piston loose on a cam or other shaft r. Air is admitted by a three-way cock T to one or other end of the cylinder b and moves either the clutch p<1>, s<2> or the clutch p<2>, s<2> into engagement, at the same time putting the port k<1> or the port k<2> into register with ports o<1>, o<3>, o<4> communicating with the engine cylinders.

A method for purging accumulated liquids from within and around a well bore in a petroleum well comprising the steps of: shutting off the well for a period of time to allow pressure to build up; fractionally opening the well for a period of time to allow the built up pressure to cause the accumulated liquids within and around the well bore to migrate to within the production tubing of the well; and then, fully opening the well flow line to purge the collected liquid hydrocarbons from within the production tubing. In a preferred aspect of this invention the method further comprises the step of positioning a plunger in a bottom portion of the production tubing prior to fractionally opening the well so that the accumulated liquids will collect above the plunger and subsequent purging will be more efficient.

column12: Improvements in the Lubrication of Internal Combustion Engines and the like.
column13: 24,351. Evans, A. F. Dec. 7. Lubricating the internal parts of gas and other engines. Fig. 1 shows the invention applied for lubricating a single-cylinder internal-combustion engine for propelling a boat. Oil from the lubricator B is fed through the passage C in the wall of the cylinder A to grooves formed on the piston D. A portion of it passes, through the passages K, L in the gudgeon-pin and the passage L<1> in the connecting-rod, to the crank J. The rapid movement of the piston and crank causes oil to be splashed on to the igniter P, the induction valve, and other parts.

column12: Improvements in Co-acting Apparatus for Railway Signalling Purposes.
Calibration of air leak detection apparatus
column13: Method and apparatus for testing leak integrity of a workpiece such as a wheel rim in which the rim is positioned within an air-tight housing with the axial rim edges is sealing engagement with opposed wall portions of the housing so as to form first and second chambers within the housing internally and externally of the rim. One of such chambers is supplied with air under pressure. Microphones are positioned in the other chamber for detecting leakage of air through the rim as a function of intensity of ultrasonic radiation emitted thereby. The test apparatus is calibrated to detect air leakage that exceeds a pre-specified maximum allowable air flow rate by removably mounting a calibration orifice on a test workpiece, with the orifice being sized to provide the pre-specified maximum allowable leakage flow rate for a satisfactory workpiece at the operating pressure of the apparatus. With the test workpiece in place, the detection electronics is adjusted to indicate an unsatisfactory workpiece when the microphone output exceeds the level associated with air flow through the test orifice.

column13: 6739. Evans, A. G. March 19. Rods and wires,for operating.-A channel-shaped troughing or housing for rods, wires, or connections for points, signals, gates, &c. has cheeks, recesses, or shelves 2 on its sides to receive the trunnions of the rollers, or it has ribs or projections screwed to its sides to hold down the roller or pulley standards such as are used for the rollers described in Specification No. 24,466, A.D. 1893. The trough sections are connected by socket joints 8, and drainage holes 7 are made in the bottom. A cover 6 is provided, but may be omitted when rods of channel-section are employed.

column12: Improvements relating to Methods of Joining Metal in Lead Acid Secondary Electric Batteries
column13: 1,174,576. Welding by pressure. ELECTRIC POWER STORAGE Ltd. 22 Dec., 1966 [24 Dec., 1965], No. 54878/65. Heading B3R. [Also in Division H1] In connecting a metal terminal pillar to a plate grid formed of dispersion strengthened lead for a lead acid secondary electric battery, a joint between the grid and the pillar or between the grid and a metal member which is itself secured to the pillar is effected by cold welding. A grid 10, Fig. 1, formed by extrusion and rolling from dispersion strengthened lead has an integral lug 11 with a tapered end 13 and this end 13 is lapped over a strip of lead alloy 12 also having a tapered end 14 in a die 15. A punch 16 having a working face 17 with semicircular ends and rounded edges is applied to the ends 12, 14 at a pressure of 12,200 p.s.i. to weld them together with 50% reduction. The bulging edges of the joint may be sheared off. The strips of a number of grids are then secured to a pillar by burning. In another embodiment, a number of dispersion strengthened lead grids 20 have integral lugs 21, Fig. 3, and these lugs are arranged in grooves 22 in a lead or lead alloy pillar 23 formed with an integral terminal and the pillar is compressed in a press to cold weld the lugs in the grooves. The materials to which the dispersion strengthened lead is cold welded may be a lead alloy containing tin and selenium or tin, calcium and silver or tin and calcium or it may be pure lead.

column12: An Improved Combined Support for the Operating Rods and Wires of Railway Points and Signalling Apparatus.
column13: 26,643. Evans, A. G. Dec. 16. Rods and wires for operating movable parts.- The standards of roller supports, such as are described in Specifications No. 13,004, A.D. 1891, No. 24,466, A.D. 1893, and Nos. 14,304 and 16,369. A.D. 1897, for the operating-rods of railway points and signals, are provided with supports for the wires used in railway signalling. In the arrangement shown, the rollers j, which support the wires m, are mounted in slots or races in the castings d, d<1>, d', d<3>, formed on the roller standards a, a'. The lateral projections e, e', &c. serve as distancepieces, and the projections l serve as guides for the wires. Small rollers j<1> may be mounted above the wires. Several modifications are described, in some of which spacing-ferrules of the kind described in Specification No. 24,466, A.D. 1893, are employed. These modifications comprise forms having only one wire-supporting roller on each pair of standards, one form having the rollers j<1> omitted, and one having the top roller b of the points rod serving as the wire-supporting roller, In another form, the wire-supporting rollers are mounted at the base of the standards.

column12: Improvements in and in connection with Admission Valves of Internal Combustion Engines.
column13: 18,855. Evans, A. F. Sept. 3. Gas and explosive-vapour engines. -The air is dried and purified in the cylinder jacket before being drawn into the engine. The valves, which in Figs. 1 and 3 are shown to admit the charge to the crank chamber, comprise an air valve F with a projection J on its spindle which opens the oil, spirit, or gas valve K. The valve F is controlled from the crank shaft by a lever D. The oil supply is regulated by a screw-down valve Q with an index V and dial W. A rail-car positioner comprises a carriage on a track running alongside and parallel to the train track and an elongate arm on the carriage is transversely displaceable to enter between a pair of coupled rail-cars of the train and connect the positioner drivingly to the train. The arm is extended substantially axially, from a retracted position on the carriage, in a preferably generally horizontal first direction to introduce an end of the arm between the pair of rail-cars, and said end is then engaged with the rail-cars' coupling by displacing it in a second direction transverse to the first direction.

column12: Multivibrator employing field effect devices as transistors and voltage variable resistors in integrated semiconductive structure

column13: A rail wheel gripper for holding or retarding a rail vehicle has opposed gripper mechanisms that engage a wheel between them. Each mechanism comprises a carrier arm for a gripper member and upper and lower pivot arms connected to the carrier arm controlling the path of movement of the gripper member. Each mechanism is so arranged, and a drive device co-operates with it, as to exhibit a mechanical advantage with increased gripping force when the opposed gripper members reach their operative positions, and a mechanical disadvantage with magnified displacement of the members when they are remote from their operative position.

column12: An Apparatus for Facilitating the Starting of Internal Combustion Engines especially Motor Car Engines.
column13: 22,793. Evans, J. A. Nov. 20. Turning-gear.-In a rack - and - pinion turning-gear, the rack x is carried on a lever g held up normally by a spring g<5>. A cord m is attached at its ends to the rack and passes over guide-pulleys o, g<4> and a sector n. The cord is attached to a lever r, which can be reciprocated from the seat of a vehicle. When the lever r is moved in the direction of the arrow, the lever moves down extending the spring g<5> until the rack is in gear with the pinion; further movement of the lever r drives the pinion. That part of the cord between the rack and the lever r which passes over the pulley o is slack during the driving movement, so that on release or arrest of the lever r, the spring g<5> immediately raises the lever g. Two racks as described above may be worked from one handle, so that a drive may be obtained from each direction of movement of the handle.

column12: Improvements relating to feeding mechanism for power presses and like machines
column13: 810,060. Metal working presses; machine-tool details. PRESS EQUIPMENT Ltd. Aug. 30, 1957 [Sept. 6, 1956], No. 27279/56. Classes 83 (3) and 83 (4). A power - driven feed - mechanism for feeding components to a powerpress or the like has a member 12 movable through a predetermined distance whilst a component is being inserted in the press, and which is arranged to interrupt the feed if it is not moved through its normal distance during insertion of the component. The feed-mechanism is of the kind described in Specifications 780,203 and 733,347 and is driven by an electric - motor 61 through a clutch 62 and gear-box 57, and includes an arm 40 oscillating horizontally about a vertical pivot 41, Fig. 5 (not shown), between extreme end-positions, i.e. a component pick-up position and a component insertion position. At these positions a platform 10 carrying the arm is rocked about a horizontal pivot, respectively to raise and lower the components. Platform 10 is connected by link 12 to a lever 18 pivoted at 17 and connected at 19 to a vertically-adjustable spindle 21 pivoted at 23 to a curved arm 24. The left-hand end of this arm has a lip 28 cooperating with a cam-projection 29 on a disc 27 secured to the output shaft of the gear-box; the right-hand end is connected to a clutch trip-rod 77. During each manual feed the lip 28 is raised out of the path of the cam 29, but if the feed-movement is less than normal due, e.g. to two components being inserted together, the lip is engaged by the cam, which moves the arm 24 to trip the rod 77 and cause it to release the clutch-engagement lever 65 as described in Specification 780,203, thereby to disengage the feed-mechanism and apply a brake. The press is also stopped. Alternatively the lever 24 may operate a switch which stops the motor 61.

column13: 126,752. Evans, J. A. July 18, 1918. Hay-loaders.-In a machine for elevating hay and like crops into wagons &c., in which the hay is pushed up a tube or channel by propellers carried by endless chains, the propellers are withdrawn from the tube while lying in a plane substantially at right-angles to the direction of movement of the hay. The endless chains a pass round sprocket wheels 3, 4, 5 mounted on a triangular frame A. The sprocket wheels 4 are driven from one of the ma.in wheels 1 by a chain 2<a>. The propellers or boards a<1> are pivotally connected to the endless chains a, and are provided with brackets or elbows a<3> which bear against the surface of the frame A and thus hold the propellers a<1> in the position shown as they pass up and withdraw from the elevator tube B. After withdrawing from the tube, the propellers engage a projection A<5> which turns them about their pivots. as shown. The hay is collected below the tube B by a rake C mounted on wheels 7, 8.

June 12, Rods and wires for operating movable parts.-Relates to supports or bearings of the kind described in Specifications No. 13,004, A.D. 1891, and No. 24,466, A.D. 1893, for the operating-rods of signals, switches, and other railway appliances. In the present invention, the spacing-ferrules f between the standards a are formed with projections f<1>, f<2>, which dovetail into the corresponding grooves d in the standards, and also serve to complete the slots or paths b for the trunnions of the upper antifriction roller. Suction and delivery valves g, h and an adjustable stop k to limit the travel of the plunger e are provided. Specification 16,188/02, [Class 7, Air and gas engines], is referred to.

A lawn mower is powered by two vertical shaft engines mounted on the chassis and equispaced about the longitudinal axis of the chassis. A vertical drive shaft is rotatably mounted on the longitudinal axis of the chassis. The outputs of both vertical shaft engines are transmitted through belts and pulleys to the vertical drive shaft, which is rotated by the combined outputs of both vertical shaft engines. Other pulleys are secured to the vertical drive shaft and connected through belting to pulleys which rotate grass-cutting blades and to pulleys which operate motors turning the driving wheels to propel the lawn mower.

column12: IMPROVEMENTS RELATING TO ELECTRIC STORAGE BATTERY CONNECTIONS
column13: 1280469 Welding by pressure ELECTRIC POWER STORAGE Ltd 23 Oct 1969 [28 Oct 1968] 50991/68 Heading B3R [Also in Division H1] In making a connection, through a partition 10, between a plate strap 12 of a lead acid electric battery cell and a companion part 20 of lead outside the cell, a rod 11 of lead extending from the plate strap through a hole or open ended slot in the partition and through an opening in the companion part is cold pressure welded to the companion part. A rod 11 of lead having a cylindrical portion 15, a frusto-conical portion 16 and a cylindrical portion 17 and formed integrally with an upstanding lug 12 of a strap of a lead acid battery is passed through a hole in an inter-cell partition 10 and through a hole 21 in a lug 20 of another plate strap. The hole 21 has a short cylindrical portion 22 and a frusto-conical portion 23, the portions 16, 17 of the rod being surrounded by the portion 22, 23 of the hole. The faces to be connected are degreased in carbon tetrachloride and cleaned with a rotary wire brush and then pressure of 8000-12,000 s.i. is applied to the end of the rod to deform it to fill, and become cold welded to, the hole in the strap lug. Instead of a hole a slot may be formed in the partition, the unoccupied part of which may be filled. Both members may be provided with openings and a separate rod with a tapered portion and cylindrical portion at each end may be cold welded to both members by pressure on its ends.

In the production of titanium dioxide by thermal hydrolysis of aqueous titanium tetrachloride the aqueous hydrochloric acid separated from the titanium dioxide is contacted with titanium tetrachloride to form gaseous hydrogen chloride and aqueous titanium tetrachloride. Mineral rutile or ilmenite or leucoxene is chlorinated and the resulting titanium tetrachloride, which may be purified by distillation in the presence of hydrocarbons, mineral oils, soaps and/or sulphides, and should contain less than 100 p.p.m. of Fe, Cr, V, Nb is dissolved in at least 20% hydrochloric acid solution to give a final concentration of 100-300 gm./1. at 35-60 DEG C. depending on acid concentration. Gaseous hydrogen chloride is evolved, dried to less than 2% water and passed over a catalyst whence chlorine is produced and used in the production of further titanium tetrachloride. The remaining titanium tetrachloride solution is added to boiling water and retained for at least seventy minutes, peptisation of the hydrous titanium dioxide being prevented by addition of polyvalent anions, e.g. sulphuric acid as flocculating agents before or during recovery. The aqueous hydrochloric acid separated from the recovered precipitate may be concentrated by addition of part of the gaseous hydrogen chloride liberated in the titanium tetrachloride dissolution before recycling to the dissolution step. The recovered hydrated titanium dioxide is calcined at 800-850 DEG C., or additioned, calcined, leached wet or dry milled in a fluid energy mill, hydroclarified, coated with hydrated oxides of Al, Ti, Zr, Si Ce, PO4 alcohols and/or alkanolamines and/or remilled to form pigmentary TiO2.

A matter-stacking and fetching machine is composed of a pitchable and rotatable supporting device with a arm-like frame construction in which there is a main arm-like frame along which there is a feeding device, an end arm-like frame protruded in opposite direction and a counterweight hangs on a pivot fixed on the end of the end arm-like frame. The end arm-like frame is greater in height than the height of the main arm-like frame to form a room for the feeding device. The counterweight may be moved by a controlling steel cable which is fastened on a not-pitchable part of the supporting device located in front of the pitchable shaft. Therefore, when the arm-like frame moves upwards in a pitching mode, the counterweight will move forward to compensate the backward move of the end of the end arm-like frame and to reduce the max. overturning moment which should be overcomed.

872,287. Weighing apparatus. HEENAN & FROUDE Ltd. May 12, 1958 [May 14, 1957], No. 15341/57. Class 143 [Also in Groups XIX, XXIX and XXXIV] An hydraulic checking and weighing gear comprises an hydraulic transmitter T and a receiver R each having a piston operating in a cylinder, fluid flow means connecting the respective cylinders whereby pressure generated in the transmitter is transmitted to the receiver, and pressure fluid bearings supporting the pistons for movement in their respective cylinders. The apparatus is shown diagrammatically in Fig. 1. A pump MP supplies oil to inlets H, H 1 , of the transmitter and receiver units T, R respectively. A pipe P interconnects the outlet ports N 1 , N 2 and ports S, S 1 are connected to the oil sump Weights W, W 1 , are placed on the transmitter and receiver, and when the system is balanced. these weights are in a predetermined ratio. Figs. 2 and 4 show the transmitter T. A piston E is freely slidable in the body of the unit and oil is supplied through restrictions r 1 , to pools G, thus forming upper and lower pressurised bearings, there being four such pools to each bearing. These bearings eliminate any metallic contact between the piston E and its housing. If the pressure of the oil in the pipe P is less than the pressure due to the weights W, the piston E falls and oil from the inlet H passes through a passage a 3 and ducts b 1 , b 2 to a passage J and then into the space K below the piston E. If the pressure of the oil is too great, the piston E rises and the passage J is opened to the drain connection S by way of an annular duct b 3 and a passage R. The pressure in the cylinder K thus balances the pressure due to the weights W, and this pressure is transmitted by the pipe P to the receiver R which consists of a piston of greater diameter supported by similar pressurised bearings in a closed cylinder to which the pipe P leads. Thus a larger weight W 1 is required to balance the weight W. Applications of the apparatus to the testing of weighing-apparatus, measuring the torque exerted by the carcase of a rotary dynamometer, and applying a known load to a strain gauge load cell or a hydrostatic capsule for testing are described. The apparatus may also act as a de-intensifier instead of an intensifier by making the transmitter piston of greater area than the receiving piston.

column13: 16,188. Evans, A. F. July 21. Gas or explosive-vapour engines.-The up-stroke of the motor piston draws air into the crank cham- ber through the valve m, and oil into the chamber g through the valve j and passage h. On the down-stroke the air is compressed in the crank chamber and in the chamber g, and at the end thereof enters the cylinder, driving out the exhaust through the port d, while the air in the chamber g expels the oil therefrom into the cylinder, where it is vaporized and the charge compressed on the up-stroke. The engine is suitable for heavy oils, which are directed by a baffle p against the hot cylinder cover n, and the chamber g is preferably heated by the exhaust. Light oil may be admitted to g at starting. The speed may be regulated by a relief valve q on the crank chamber.

A flag pole mounted unfurling device is installed on a flagpole and rotates to minimize the unwanted furling of the flag. The device includes a lower swivel, an upper swivel, and a baton that extends between the lower swivel and the upper swivel to retain the two swivels in alignment and properly separated. The upper swivel and lower swivel are free to rotate around the axis of the pole while the baton serves to couple the upper and lower swivels together, both rotationally and longitudinally. The entire assembly is longitudinally retained on the pole by an upper collar and a lower collar and minimizes the unwanted furling of a flag through ‘dynamic instability.’

column12: Operator controlled deflector plate for discharge chute of riding lawn mower
column13: The exit end of the discharge chute of a riding lawn mower having rotating grass-cutting blades is provided with a rotatable deflector plate, the position of which is controlled through a linkage by the operator of the lawn mower while seated and without stopping the lawn mower. The operator, through the linkage, can shift the deflector plate between an operative position closing the exit end of the discharge chute, an inoperative position opening the said exit end, and positions therebetween. The deflector plate is provided with apertures of size and spacing sufficient to prevent the passage therethrough of stones large enough to cause physical injury to persons or damage to property in the vicinity of the exit end, while permitting the passage therethrough of grass cuttings, small stones having no potential to cause such physical injury or property damage, and air forced through the discharge chute by action of the grass-cutting blades.

column12: Improvements in or relating to nuclear magnetic resonance apparatus
column13: 995, 236. Gyromagnetic resonance apparatus. MULLARD Ltd. June 29, 1961 [June 29, 1960], No. 22785/60. Heading G1N. The radio-frequency coil of a gyromagnetic resonance apparatus comprises a conductor of rectangular cross-section wherein the width of the conductor is very much greater than its thickness. Glass cylinder 1 Fig. 1, is electroplated with a thin layer of copper between limits 2, 3 and portions are etched away to form a coil 6 with end strips 13, 14, channels 9-12 being etched away to break what would otherwise be a short circuited turn. The length of the copper plated region should be many times the coil length and the major part of the end portions should be left in situ. Rigorous chemical cleansing to remove the etching agent (ferric chloride) is stated to be essential if false readings are to be avoided, and the arrangement is said to give a high Q value. The use of such a coil in a spinning sample type apparatus in which the unidirectional field is swept is described with reference to Fig. 2 (not shown). Specification 640,878 is referred to.

1,253,973. Liquid level control. DISTILLERS CO. (CARBON DIOXIDE) Ltd. Jan. 13, 1970 [Oct.22, 1968], No. 50060/68. Heading G1H. In equipment in which beer is drawn by a pump from a bulk container through a pipe 1 into a glass cylinder 3 and leaves through a pipe 2, a reed switch 4 is arranged adjacent or above the pipe 1 and a float containing a magnet 9, floats on the beer, the arrangement is such that as carbon dioxide gas collects in the cylinder 3 the beer level 18 and hence the float 5 drops until the magnet 9 actuates switch 4 to close a contact in a switch 10 to isolate a circuit 11, controlling the pump, and complete a circuit to a warning lamp. A valve 7 is manually operated to allow all the gas to escape through a pipe 6 and then closed and a push button operated to resume normal operation. In a modification, Fig. 2 (not shown) the float is provided with two magnets and two reed switches one of which is in circuit with the valve 6.

column12: New or improved means for controlling the working of strip material
column13: 802,704. Metal strip feeds. PRESS EQUIPMENT, Ltd. April 10, 1957 [April 10, 1956], No. 10884/56. Class 83 (4). [Also in Group XVI] Strip is fed to abut against a stop beyond the tools or dies of a machine which operate on the strip and as it reaches the stop the strip actuates a switch associated with or adjacent the stop to arrest or slow down the feed and to set the machine in motion to operate on the strip. Strip is fed from a reel 12 by feeding and straightening rolls 14 through a press 10 to abut the stop 24 which determines the length to be cut. The stop 24 consists of a housing 31 carrying the stop member 30 and mounted on a bell-crank lever 45 pivoted on a bracket 34 adjustably secured to a frame 21. A threaded rod engaging the housing 31 and a boss on the bell-crank lever 46 provides a fine adjustment of the stop. When the strip engages a flap 44, the switch 41 is actuated to slow or stop the feed and providing the press ram is at top-dead centre to pneumatically actuate a one-revolution clutch controlling the press. Just after the strip is sheared, a cam on the crank-shaft of the press actuates a valve to pass compressed air temporarily to cylinders 47, 53 which serve respectively to raise the stop-member 30 and to operate a pushbar which pushes the severed strip into a bin 26. The switch 41 releases and the feed rate is returned to normal. When the switch merely slows the feed rate the strip forms a hump 11 on the feed side of the press and this hump may be used to control an arm 83 to vary or stop the feed as an additional control during normal working or to stop the feed should the strip jam in the press. In a press used for blank punching, the stop engages the edge of an opening formed in the strip by a previous operation and is momentarily retracted during the feeding of the strip to clear the web between adjacent openings.

A flag pole mounted unfurling device is installed on a flagpole and rotates to minimize the unwanted furling of the flag. The device includes a lower swivel, an upper swivel, and a baton that extends between the lower swivel and the upper swivel to retain the two swivels in alignment and properly separated. The upper swivel and lower swivel are free to rotate around the axis of the pole while the baton serves to couple the upper and lower swivels together, both rotationally and longitudinally. The entire assembly is longitudinally retained on the pole by an upper collar and a lower collar and minimizes the unwanted furling of a flag through ‘dynamic instability.’

A stacker-reclaimer has a luffing and slewing mounting (2, 4) supporting a boom structure with a main, forwardly extending boom (14) having material-conveying means running along it, and a rearwardly extending tail boom (22) with a counterbalance weight (34) depending from its rear end. The tail boom is at a higher level than the main boom to provide clearance of a feeder conveyor (26) to the material-conveying means. The counterbalance weight is attached by a pivot (30) on the tail boom and is displaceable about the pivot by a control cable (36) attached to a non-luffing part (40) of the luffing and slewing mounting forwards of the luffing axis (6) whereby the weight is displaced forwards in relation to the pivot in upward luffing movements of the boom structure. This compensates for the rearward displacement of the rear end of the tail boom in such movements, and reduces the maximum overturning moment to be resisted in the working luffing range.

column12: Improvements in or relating to charge machines for nuclear reactors
column13: 972,734. Fuelling reactors. UNITED POWER CO. Ltd. Oct. 4, 1963 [July 5, 1962], No, 25855/62. Heading G6C. A charge machine 1 is rotatably supported by a shoulder 2 and bearing 3 on an annular structure 4 having wheels 8 surrounding the machine 1 at its lower end. The wheels 8 are single wheels and a plurality are provided arranged on parallel axes around the structure 4, each wheel having an axle 9 carried by an arm 10 pivotally connected at one end to a bracket 11 fixed to the structure. The other end of the arm 10 is connected to the ram 12 of a hydraulic ram assembly 13 so that by extending the rams the machine 1 is raised clear of the reactor charge floor 21 to permit movement of the structure 4 by driving the wheels 8, whereas by retracting the rams, the machine 1 rests on the floor 21 and the wheels 8 are raised clear of the floor. In this condition the structure 4 may be rotated on the machine 1 by operating a motor 18 mounted on the structure, this motor driving a pinion 19 meshing with an annular gear 20 fixed to the machine. Thus the wheels 8 may be orientated so that when they support the machine on the surface 21 the machine is driven in the desired direction. Each wheel 8 may have its own driving motor (Fig. 2, not shown) and this motor may be electric or hydraulic. In a modification (not shown) the arms 10 are omitted and the wheels 8 are mounted directly on the lower ends of telescopic rams. T.V. cameras may be mounted beneath the structure 4 to observe the standpipe with which the machine is to be aligned.

[Also in Division G1] A reciprocating generator for measuring linear velocity comprises a cylindrical magnet assembly magnetized radially to produce a substantially uniform field over its length, and a coil 7 (Fig. 2) assembled round the magnet and attached to a moving member 9, whereby the voltage output from the coil is proportional to the speed of movement. The cylindrical assembly consists of a stack of similar ferrite permanent magnet rings 2 of like polarity . threaded on to a soft iron core 1. The moving coil 7 may alternatively be located between the magnet rings and the core. In a modification (Fig. 5, not shown), two permanent magnets M1, M2 are located at the ends of a soft iron cylindrical core to produce the radial magnetic field.

column12: Apparatus for the vaporisation of liquids
column13: 882,878. Automatic temperature control systems. DISTILLERS CO. Ltd. March 4, 1960 [March 7, 1959], No. 7967/59. Class 38 (4). [Also in Group XXVIII] Vaporizing apparatus for a readily vaporizable liquid such as liquid carbon dioxide or liquid petroleum gases comprises a heating vessel 1 having an inlet port 2 for connection to a storage tank containing the vaporizable liquid and an outlet port 4 for connection to a gas delivery pipe 5, the heating vessel containing three heating elements 7, 8, 9 with an associated temperature responsive device 10, 11, 12 respectively, the temperature responsive devices controlling the supply to the heating elements. Whilst the vaporizer is idle, the liquid vaporizes until the liquid pressure is balanced by the gas pressure in the vessel 1. Opening of a valve 6 allows the gas to be used with a consequent further generation of gas in the vessel 1 with a concomitant drop in the temperature in the vessel. The passage of the liquid through the inlet port 2 causes a temperature responsive device to operate to close a switch 17 whereby the electric supply circuit is closed. The drop of temperature in the vessel 1 causes the temperature responsive devices 10, 11, 12 to operate in succession to close switches 13, 14, 15 respectively so that the heating elements 7, 8, 9 maintain the supply of gas. As the demand for gas diminishes, the temperature at the top of the vessel rises, whereupon the temperature responsive device 12 causes the heating element 9 to be switched off. A further reduction in demand will cause the heating element 8 to be switched off and so on. Other temperature responsive devices, to control the heating elements, may be placed in the delivery pipe 5. A fusible link 26 is provided adjacent the vessel 1 which link ruptures should the temperature of the vessel rise above a predetermined limit, whereupon a switch 25 opens to remove the electric supply from the apparatus. The heating means may be other than electric, such as for example, steam.

column12: New or improved safety mechanism for power presses and other power-driven machines or machine tools
column13: 727,914. Machinery guards. PRESS GUARDS, Ltd. Oct. 29, 1953 [Sept. 15, 1952], No. 23088/52. Class 80 (4). [Also in Group XXXIV] A safety mechanism for a press or milling or other machine comprises a brake applied to a rotating part by a lever which, in the event of danger to an operator (such as on the opening of a guard, operation of a trip bar, or interruption of a light beam), is moved into the path of a cam or other member on the rotating part and applies the brake through a member having a limited yielding movement to relieve the stresses in the brake. As shown, a pair of brake shoes 12, 13, pivoted on a fixed stud 14 are normally held by a spring 20 in light engagement with a drum on the crank-shaft 11 of a press to bring it to rest when the clutch (not shown) is disengaged. A movable guard (not shown) is linked to a lever 26 so that when the guard is opened a horn 23 on a lever 24 is moved into the path of a cam 22 on the crankshaft. The lever 24 carries a roller 31 engaging a surface 32 on the shoe 13, and is pivoted to a link 30 which is pivoted on a pin 33 slidable, against a frictional resistance provided by spring washers or springs, in a slot in the shoe 12. Should the press over-run while the guard is open, the roller 31 is moved over the surface 32 to give a braking pressure additional to that provided by the spring 20, said pressure being limited by the slidable connection 33. Should the brake fail to stop the crank-shaft, the roller 31 engages a projection 37 to provide a positive stop. The cam 22 may be shaped to hold the guard closed during the down stroke of the press, or during the down stroke and part of the up stroke. A switch 38 controlling the driving motor is carried by a lever 39 pivoted to the link 30 and is normally held closed against a flat on a pin 18 on the shoe 13, the end of the lever 39 bearing on the end of a pin 36 which locks the nut of the connection 33. When the brake intensifier is operated the lever 39 is rocked to open the switch 38 and de-energize the driving motor. The switch 38 also provides a warning that the brake shoes need relining, since if the shoes move together more than a predetermined amount the switch 38 rides off the flat on the pin 18 and the motor cannot be started. Should the brake become locked on the drum the pin 36 may be withdrawn and the connection 33 slackened to release the brake, the pin 36 ensuring that the connection is subsequently returned to its original setting. A spring-pressed radial pawl 41 in the path of the cam 22 prevents reverse rotation of the crank-shaft. In a modification an axially-moving pawl co-operates with a notch in the end face of the brake drum. It is stated that the pawl may be withdrawn by the closing of the guard or by the movement of a clutch lever. In a further construction of brake control, Fig. 3 (not shown), the frictional connection 33 is replaced by a resilient connection comprising a compression spring ; the switch 38 is replaced by a switch carried by the brake shoe 13 and operated by an extension of the link connecting the two shoes ; and the spring- loaded pawl 41 is replaced by a gravity-loaded pawl. It is stated that the brake shoes may be replaced by a band brake. For milling and like machines having a continuously-rotating shaft, the cam is replaced by a toothed wheel or serrated disc adapted to apply the brake. According to the Provisional Specification, a guard is coupled to a bell-crank co-operating with the crank-shaft cam, the bell-crank pivoting on a pin which carries a roller engaging an inclined surface on one brake shoe and is yieldingly linked to the other shoe.

column13: 10,366. Evans, A. F. May 2, 1912, [Convention date]. Actuating by pulsating fluid pressure.-Apparatus of the type in which a pneumatically actuated differential fuel pump is used to inject fuel into the cylinder of an internal-combustion engine, has the air-timing valve in the form of a plunger worked by the engine. The compressed air, which may be obtained from the engine cylinder or independently, is admitted by the valve t to the cylinder m. The piston l, connected to the plunger a of the fuelpump, is moved against the pressure of the spring h which returns the moving parts to their initial positions. The cylinder is provided with a regulating-screw o for regulating the amount of fuel delivered at each stroke, and with water jackets m<1>, n<1>. column12: Measuring unit for measuring off lengths of material
column13: 962,552. Measuring continuous lengths. PRESS EQUIPMENT Ltd Sept. 4, 1961 [June 3, 1960], No. 19670/60. Heading G1M. A measuring unit for measuring off lengths of material which is fed by a feed device, said unit comprising a switch actuating member, an electrically controlled clutch through which the switch actuating member is driven at the same time as the material is fed, a measuring switch which is actuated by the switch-actuating member to deenergize the clutch after the member has been driven through a spatial interval corresponding to the desired length, means for selecting the magnitude of the spatial interval, a starting switch which is actuated by the switch-actuating member, to energize the clutch, after the member has been returned through the spatial interval to an initial position, and means for returning the switch-actuating member to the initial position. As shown a shaft 11a driven by movement of the feed roll of the material is connected by an electromagnetic clutch 18a to a rotor arm 23a with projections 32a, 40a. Rotation of arm 23a from its starting position causes the projection 40a to operate a measuring switch 33a adjustably mounted on a block 16 so that the length to be measured off can be adjusted. A shaft 11b driven by shaft 11a through reduction gearing 17 is similarly provided with an arm 23b and switch 33b. When both switches 33a, 33b are in the operated position, the feed stops, the clutch 18a is disconnected and a rewind motor 26 is operated to return arms 23a, 23b to the starting position where projections 32a, 32b operate starting switches 27a, 27b through members 29a, 29b to re-engage clutch 18a. Dials 34a, 34b are provided to set the position of measuring switches 33a, 33b and these dials may be adapted to compensate for over-run of the feed rolls after the drive thereto is stopped.

column13: 堆取料装置，有一支承臂架结构的俯仰和旋转支承装置，臂架结构有：一主臂架，沿主臂架设有输送装置；一反向伸出的尾臂架，一平衡块垂挂在尾臂架末端的一枢轴上。尾臂架高于主臂架，以便为供料输送装置留出空间。平衡块可以靠一控制钢丝绳移动，钢丝绳系在俯仰轴前面支承装置的不俯仰部件上，因此在臂架结构作向上俯仰移动时平衡块向前移动，这就补偿了此时尾臂架末端的向后移动，并减小了需要克服的最大倾覆力矩。

column13: 24,349. Evans, A. F. Dec. 7. Exhaust-silencers. -The spent gases from an internalcombustion engine or elsewhere are discharged by the pipe G through a nozzle C into a closed buffer chamber A, whence between the successive injections the gases escape through a perforated plate D and a chamber K filled with coke or other material.

A stacker-reclaimer has a luffing and slewing mounting (2, 4) supporting a boom structure with a main, forwardly extending boom (14) having material-conveying means running along it, and a rearwardly extending tail boom (22) with a counterbalance weight (34) depending from its rear end. The tail boom is at a higher level than the main boom to provide clearance of a feeder conveyor (26) to the material-conveying means. The counterbalance weight is attached by a pivot (30) on the tail boom and is displaceable about the pivot by a control cable (36) attached to a non-luffing part (40) of the luffing and slewing mounting forwards of the luffing axis (6) whereby the weight is displaced forwards in relation to the pivot in upward luffing movements of the boom structure. This compensates for the rearward displacement of the rear end of the tail boom in such movements, and reduces the maximum overturning moment to be resisted in the working luffing range.

column12: Improvements in Multicolor Rotary Lithographic Machines.
column13: 18,215. Evans, A. B. Sept. 8. Printing in several colours.-In multi-colour rotary lithographic machines, the tripping- mechanism for the plate cylinders b is self-contained on each cylinder b, double-ended rocking levers o on the cylinders b effecting the shifting (directly or indirectly) under the control of an adjustable projecting part on the cylinder a. The lever o is shown as connected with a cam-lever p determining the travel of a roller lever s upon the inside or outside of a broken ring t on the cylinder b. The lever s rocks the eccentric bearing z through connexions u, v, x, y. Projecting rollers n<4> for engagement with the levers o are carried on the cylinder a by arms on rock-shafts n retained by spring rods n<1>, n<2>. The rock-shafts n are actuated by means of other arms provided with rollers n<3> for engagement by faces m', m<3> of a cam m<1> shifted by means of a pedal e. The cam m<1> is on a guided bar m pivoted to a bell-crank k. When the pedal e is depressed, a cam-actuated latch i is engaged with the bellcrank k, and the cam m<1> is raised. When the pedal e is released, the part i is disengaged by means of springs g<3>, h', and the cam m<1> drops. The cylinder a is subdivided into four sections d, d<1>, d<2>, d<3> separated by gaps, in two of which are grippers c, c'.

column12: Improvements relating to the Inking Rollers of Printing Machines.
column13: 8977. Evans, A. B. April 28. Inking-apparatus.- Relates to means for lifting the inking-rollers, of printing-machines away from the printing.surface without disturbing the rider-rollers. The inking- rollers b, b<1> are carried by arms.c, c<1> which are pivoted on the shaft of the rider a. To the shafts of the inking-rollers or to the arms c, c<1> are pivoted links d, the lower ends of which are pivoted to a rod e. By lifting the rod e, the inking-rollers b, b<1> are raised without disturbing.the rider a. In a modification, the links dare parallel and are pivoted to a horizontally-sliding rod or to the circumference of a wheel.

The pin f is formed with an eye f' through which and through an elongated hole b<2> in the head of the pin b passes a lifting- ring g. column12: Improvements in mechanism for feeding blanks or components to power presses and likemachines
column13: 847,810. Feeding sheets. PRESS EQUIPMENT Ltd. March 4, 1957 [Dec. 2, 1955; March 7, 1956], Nos. 34516/55 and 7154/56. Class 100(1) Single sheet feeds; control &c. devices :- Mechanism for feeding blanks or components to power presses &c, comprises mechanism driven as a unit and serving to pick up components and to feed them into and remove them from intermittently operating tools, in combination with automatically operating safety means whereby the feeding mechanism is stopped or the setting in motion of the means for actuating the tools is prevented if the various steps in the feeding of a component do not take place normally in relation to the operation of the tools. The feeding mechanism may be applied to a single press, or for feeding components through a number of sets of tools in separate presses assembled in line. In the form shown in Figs. 1 and 3, the press is one of a number of power presses operating sequentially on blanks or components which are fed from one press to other by suction grippers 34. Each frame 10 is open in end view, the frames are all in one straight line, and the tools and blank feeding means of each press are driven from a crankshaft 11. The feeding means comprises a stationary longitudinally extending bar 12, and a carriage 13 mounted for vertical movements thereon by means of bell-crank levers 14 pivoted at 15. The vertical arms of these levers are connected together by rods 17, and one of the vertical arms is connected to the piston rod of a fluid-pressure cylinder 18, which causes raising and lowering of the carriage 13. Sliding movement is imparted to the carriage 13 by a rod 21, a lever 22 secured on a shaft 23 mounted in a frame bracket, an arm 25 secured on the shaft 23, a rod 26 of adjustable length, and a bell-crank lever 27 which urges the rod 26 through the medium of two compression springs 30. The other end of the lever 27 carries a roller engaging a cam groove 29 in a face cam fixed on the crankshaft 11. The stroke of this drive assembly is limited by micrometer stops 33 on the lever 22 co-operating with fixed abutments. Two suction pick-up heads 34, spaced at intervals on the carriage 13 equal to half the spacing between the tools of adjacent presses, are connected through a valve 36 and a flexible pipe to a source of vacuum. The shape of the cam groove 29 is such that the feed assembly 12, 13 is stationary ion a neutral position in which the pick-up heads 34 are midway between the tools of adjacent presses, the assembly then moves in one direction to bring the first head 34 over a loading table and the second head 34 over the bottom tool &c. of the press. The carriage 13 is now lowered, blanks &c. are picked up from the loading table and tools, respectively, by the two heads 34, the carriage is raised, the assembly is moved in the opposite direction to carry the blank from the loading table above the tools of the press, and blank from the press over the next loading table. The carriage is now lowered and the blanks released. The loading tables may be omitted, and the pick-up heads may transfer the blariks from the tools of one press to the next. The safety control mechanism, shown in Fig. 3, includes a connecting pipe 42 between one suction pick-up head 34 to a vacuum switch 43 in series with a switch 44 controlled by a cam 45 on the press crankshaft 11. These switches are in the circuit of a solenoid 46 of a valve 47 which controls a compressed air cylinder 48 for operating the extractor 49 of the key clutch of the press. If a blank or component is not picked up by either of the suction heads 34, the switch 43 remains closed and, when the switch 44 is closed, the solenoid 46 is energised and opens the valve 47 which energises the cylinder 48 and the extractor 49 is retracted, whereupon the clutch is not engaged and the press does not make its next stroke. The cylinder 18 for raising and lowering the carriage 13 is supplied with compressed air through a valve controlled by, a solenoid in a circuit containing a switch which is closed twice by cams during each rotation of the crankshaft 11. The air cylinder 18 may be single acting, in which case the carriage 13 is lowered by a spring or under gravity. In the modification shown diagrammatically in Fig. 8, the blank &c. feeding means is driven independently of the press, and is controlled by a motor-driven cam shaft 80 (not shown) which also controls the starting operations of the press. As before, a stationary bar has a gripper carriage 61 mounted for vertical movements thereon by bell-crank levers, and the carriage is reciprocated over the bar by a double-ended compressed air cylinder 63 divided by a central partition into two aligned cylinders, the piston of one being connected to a fixed member, and the piston of the other being connected bv a linkage to the feed carriage. The carriage 61, which is raised and lowered by a compressed air cylinder 70, carries a number of spaced grippers each having pairs of jaws operated by an air cylinder 74 associated with a detector switch 76 which is actuated if the jaws fail to grip a blank or component. The press is set in motion when a pedal 78 is depressed by an air cylinder 77. The cam shaft 80 (not shown) is driven from an electric motor, and cams 79 thereon control air valves 93, 96 and 97 in a compressed air system, and electric switches 108 and 111. Compressed air from a main pipe 92 passes through the valve 93 to the cylinder 70, through a valve 94 to the cylinders 74 of the grippers, through a solenoidoperated valve 95 and the valves 96, 97 to the double-ended cylinder 63, and through a pipe 105 and a solenoid-operated valve 106 to the cylinder 77. A switch 98 in the circuit of the valve 95 is actuated by a cam 99 on the crankshaft 100 of the press. When the press is started, the switch 98 is closed, the solenoid valve 95 is closed to cut off air to the valves 96, 97, but air is allowed to pass by way of pilot line 101 and shuttle valves 102, 103 to return the feeding mechanism to a neutral position, if it is not already there. In the circuit of the valve 106, a switch 107 is closed by the carriage 61 when the latter returns to neutral position, and the switch 108 is operated by a cam 79. If the carriage has not returned to the neutral position, the solenoid is not energised and the press is not set in motion. A branch air pipe 109 between the valve 106 and air cylinder 77 leads to a pressure operated switch 110 which is normally open but is closed when the cylinder 77 is energised. This switch is in parallel with the cam-operated switch 111 in the circuit of the motor driving the cam shaft 80 (not shown), and the switch 111 is in series with the detector switches 76 on the grippers for the blanks &c. If either of the grippers fails to pick up a blank the corresponding switch 76 opens and the motor is stopped. If the carriage 61 has not returned to neutral position, the cylinder 77 is not energised to trip the press clutch, the switch 110 will not be closed, and the cam shaft motor is stopped. The motor is controlled by a starter unit 112 and control unit 113. The valve 94 is opened by the downward movement of the carriage 61 so that the gripper cylinders 74 are energised to close the grippers on to the blanks &c. The spacing of the grippers and the cycle of operations of the feeding assembly is substantially as described in respect of Figs. 1 and 3. Grippers:-The grippers used in the second construction each comprise an angularly adjustable arm, two gripper jaws pivotally mounted at the outer end of the arm so that the two inner limbs of the jaws engage a wedge which is moved along the arm to open and close the jaws, an air cylinder 74, Fig. 8, mounted on the arm and connected with the wedge, and a detector switch 76, Fig. 8, also on the arm and which is actuated if the travel of the wedge exceeds a predetermined amount owing to the failure of the jaws to grasp a blank or component. When the switch 76 is actuated, the motor driving the main cam shaft is stopped.

column12: Improvements in Gearing for Motor Cars and the like.
column13: 7893. Evans, A. F. April 9. Motor road vehicles.-Change speed gearing for motor-cars &c. is arranged with two driving-shafts 9, 1 geared together and rotating in opposite directions, and a .driven shaft 5 in line with the shaft 9. The shaft 9 carries a fast clutch member 10, and the shaft 5 a movable member 10<1> secured thereto. The shaft 1 carries a fast clutch member 2 and a loose movable member 2<1> secured to a toothed pinion 3. The pinion 3 is constantly in mesh with a wheel 4, loose on the shaft 5 and carrying ratchet teeth 6, engaged by pawls 7 carried by a disk 8 secured to the shaft 5. Normally, the friction clutches are both held in engagement by springs, and a direct high-speed drive is effected, the pawls 7 overrunning the teeth 6. On depressing a pedal, a cam lever 12 is rotated, disengaging the clutch 10, 10'. The pawls 7 then pick up the teeth 6, and the shaft 5 is driven at a reduced speed from the shaft 1. Farther movement of the pedal disengages the clutch 2, 2<1> by means of a cam-lever 11, and gives a "free " engine. Reversal is effected by reversing the engine and clutching the gear 4 positively to the shaft 5 by pins 16 engaging recesses 19 in the disk 8.

column13: 780,861. Metal strip feeds ; unwinding. PRESS EQUIPMENT, Ltd. Oct. 17, 1955 [Oct. 15, 19541, No. 29719/54. Class 83 (4). In mechanism for feeding metal strip to a press, feeding and straightening rolls 17 are driven by an electric motor 24 through a variable - speed hydraulic transmission unit 22 which is controlled by an arm 41 resting on the strip or by switches engaged by the strip to adjust the feeding rate to the requirements of the press. The strip is drawn from a reel 12 mounted on rollers 13 which may be idle or geared to the feeding rolls 17 and is guided between laterally adjustable plates 14 and vertical rolls 18. The transmission unit 22 may be preset manually. Rolls 43 controlled by the press 45 feed the strip to the press. The arm 41 varies the speed ratio of the transmission unit 22 continuously in dependence on the size of the loop. In a modification micro-switches engaged by the loop control a slave motor which adjusts the transmission unit 22 to a high or low-speed position. As shown in Fig. 5, the strip is fed by rolls across a flat table to the press and engages a fixed stop 51 if the press is a shearing press or a retractable stop if the press is a punching press to form a hump 52 on which rests the control arm 41.

column12: Improvements in hydraulic dynamometers and brakes
column13: 734,024. Dynamometers. HEENAN & FROUDE, Ltd. Dec. 9, 1953 [Sept. 11, 1952], No. 22779/52. Class 106 (2). [Also in Group XXXIV] In a hydraulic fluid absorption dynamometer, Fig. 1, the stationary power absorbing vanes l on the carcase are disposed between the power absorbing vanes a of the rotor, each half rotor a having thrower surfaces which prevent or retard the escape of working fluid from the casing. Working fluid is admitted to the dynamometer through holes in the stationary vanes l. Non-contact seals or labyrinths e are arranged to reduce the axial flow of liquid along the shaft, any such liquid being eventually thrown off by throwers to drain off spaces h. The outside flat surface of each half rotor a remote from the stationary power absorbing vanes l is formed with radial vanes d, comprising said thrower surfaces, to resist flow of fluid away from the dynamometer. Figs. 9 and 10 show a method of giving access to the interior of the dynamometer. The stationary vanes l are split on the line l1, each half being attached to an inspection cover p bolted to the casing. By removing these covers the interior of the dynamometer is exposed to view. Specification 656,105 is referred to.

column13: In the production of zirconium tetrachloride by the reaction of chlorine with a fluidised bed of a zirconia-silica compound such as zircon, in the presence of a reducing agent, preferably carbon, a zirconium-containing additive which reacts highly exothermically with chlorine is fed to the bed to maintain the required high temperature thereof. The additive is added in amount less than and preferably 10-80% by weight of, the zirconiasilica compound employed; suitable additives are zirconium cyanonitride, nitride or carbide or impure zirconium metal such as dross, cuttings or turnings. Zircon of particle size from 76-250 microns may be employed in admixture with carbon, preferably petroleum coke, in a proportion of 4 to 1. The reactor employed is provided with a perforated base plate across which pressure drop is 1/2 to 50 times the pressure drop across the bed. Zirconium and silicon tetrachlorides are formed and condensed in separate chambers. Specifications 794,666 and 813,489 are referred to.

column12: Plenum drying hopper with integral heaters
column13: A plenum drying hopper for granular material includes a housing enclosing a plenum chamber, an upper material inlet for introducing a flow of granular material into the plenum chamber, and a perforate diffuser cone, located in the lower portion of the plenum chamber, that directs the granular material from the plenum chamber into a material outlet. The perforations in the diffuser cone are large enough to permit ready passage of gas therethrough but small enough to preclude passage of all but the finest particles of the granular material. A gas inlet extends into the lower portion of the housing for introducing a drying gas (air) into the plenum chamber; a gas outlet discharges the gas from the upper part of the housing. Heaters are provided for heating the gas prior to its entry into the plenum chamber. The improvement comprises a deflection shield structure mounted in the housing below the plenum chamber between the heaters and the diffuser cone, that directs heated air along a labyrinthine path from the heaters through the diffuser cone and into the plenum chamber. It also shields the diffuser cone from the heaters to prevent radiant heat from reaching the diffuser cone, and deflects fine particles of the granular material that pass through the diffuser cone directly into the material outlet.

column12: PLENUM DRYING HOPPER WITH INTEGRAL HEATERS
column13: PLENUM DRYING HOPPER WITH INTEGRAL HEATERS A plenum drying hopper for granular material includes a housing enclosing a plenum chamber, an upper material inlet for introducing a flow of granular material into the plenum chamber, and a perforate diffuser cone, located in the lower portion of the plenum chamber, that directs the granular material from the plenum chamber into a material outlet. The perforations in the diffuser cone are large enough to permit ready passage of gas therethrough but small enough to preclude passage of all but the finest particles of the granular material. A gas inlet extends into the lower portion of the housing for introducing a drying gas (air) into the plenum chamber; a gas outlet discharges the gas from the upper part of the housing. Heaters are provided for heating the gas prior to its entry into the plenum chamber. The improvement comprises a deflection shield structure mounted in the housing below the plenum chamber between the heaters and the diffuser cone, that directs heated air along a labyrinthine path from the heaters through the diffuser cone and into the plenum chamber. It also shields the diffuser cone from the heaters to prevent radiant heat from reaching the diffuser cone, and deflects fine particles of the granular material that pass through the diffuser cone directly into the material outlet.

column12: Improvements in Means for Locking Nuts.
column13: 10,945. Kirton, A. E., [Hughes, J. H.]. May 5. Locking nuts.-A nut a and washer bare formed with correspondingly inclined meeting faces so that when the nut is screwed down upon the work with the washer in the position shown, any movement of the nut upon the washer causes a wedging action. The washer is made of the same external shape as the nut, and the incline upon the nut and washer from one corner to the diametrically opposite corner'. The under face of the washer may be serrated, and positioning-marks g may be provided on the nut and washer.
