column13: 812,777. Automatic temperature control systems. TEXAS INSTRUMENTS Inc. Nov. 19, 1956, No. 35320/56. Class 38 (4). In a system for controlling the temperature of an electric furnace supplied through at least one grid controlled gaseous discharge device, a D.C. error voltage is derived from a D.C. voltage indicative of furnace temperature and converted to an A.C. voltage wherein the phase and magnitude are indicative of the error, the A.C. being added to a further A.C. voltage to produce a phase modulated sine wave signal which is converted to time spaced voltage spikes for controlling the firing of the tube. The difference in voltage between a thermocouple 15, Fig. 2, in an induction furnace 13 from which it is desired to draw a germanium crystal and a thermocouple 17 in melting ice, is opposed by a battery 30 in a potentiometer 19-26 to produce a zero error signal input to chopper 31 at the predetermined temperature. The chopper output, after amplification and shaping in a unit 35 is applied with an alternating voltage from phase A to the two grids of a double-triode 36 having a common anode load 40, a phase difference of 90 degrees being achieved by a phase-shifting network 3 7 in the phase A supply. A sine wave signal is thus produced in line 42 the phase of which changes with crucible temperature and when applied to phase-shifting network 43 produces at the grids of " thyratrons " 51-53 which are normally negatively biased. Three spiked pulses at identical time positions with respect to the cycles of the three phases of the mains supply, the time position being determined by the signal phase so that the input power to the furnace and thus the furnace temperature is continuously controlled. A meter 125 is provided for the initial adjustment of the system and thermocouples of platinum and 90 per cent platinum, 10 per cent rhodium are stated to be most satisfactory. The system may be modified for any number of phases and for full-wave working. In a modification, Fig. 3, a self-balancing potentiometer 60 is introduced and the chopper and phase modulating valve 36 are replaced, between terminals 27, 28 and 58, 59, by a continuously variable phaseshifting circuit including a saturable reactor 72 the control winding of which is in the anode circuit of an amplifier valve 66. Improved sensitivity to sudden changes is provided by a resistor 67 and a condenser 68, and internal feed-back is produced by R.F. induction in a single turn pick-up 79 placed near the generator output coils. A stabilizing rate-of-change signal which is applied also to the grid of amplifier 66 is derived from a quartz rod 92 in heat transfer relation with the furnace, and a photo-electric cell 93 which detects the infrared emission therefrom. A cam programme arrangement, which utilizes a reversible motor to adjust the datum set by the potentiometer whereby the temperature may be controlled in conjunction with the withdrawal of the crystal is described with reference to Fig. 5 (not shown). Performance figures for the system are given and the operation of the continuously variable phase-shifting network is described.

Improvements in or relating to stapling devices
column13: 781,770. Stapling machines. AERO ZIPP FASTENERS, Ltd. Aug. 4, 1955 [Aug. 9, 1954], No. 23078/54. Class 89(3) A stapling device for securing a staplelike stop member 10, Fig. 5, to a slide fastener or a pair of slide fasteners, comprises a driving plunger 3, Fig. 1, a reciprocatable towards and away from a stapling anvil 2, the plunger having at its lower end two clips 22, Fig. 8, having inwardly bent lower parts 23 between which a stop member 10 is received from a passageway defined between two curved guides 13, 15, Fig. 4. The clips 22 are pivoted to a pin 28 slidable in a slot 34 in the plunger 3 and are biased inwardly at their lower ends 23 by springs 32 to hold the stop member 10 at the lower end of the plunger 3 during downward movement of the plunger, until the prongs 16, 17 of the stop member 10 engage the anvil 2, in which position further downward movement of the clips 22 is prevented by engagement of the pin 28 with shoulders 35 in brackets 31. Thereafter continuing downward movement of the plunger 3 to clinch the prongs 16, 17 forces stop member 10 downwardly past the clip ends 23 causing the clips 22 to yield outwardly to release the stop member. Upon upward movement of the plunger 3 after the clinching operation the clips 22 are moved into their original position to receive another stop member 10 from the passageway between the guides 13, 15. The stop members 10 are fed to the guides 13,15 from a hopper 7 which includes a baffle 14 for ensuring that the stop members pass one at a time to a bridge 12 connecting the guide 13 to the hopper 7. Deflecting surfaces are incorporated in the bridge 12 for tipping any sideways lying stop members on to their backs, while other stop members are rejected from the bridge 12 on meeting the guide 15, and fall through an opening 20 thereof or from the end of the bridge into a container 21. The machine is operated through a lever 5, either by a treadle or electrically. The hopper 7 may be vibrated, either by hand or by lever 5. The clips 22 may be replaced by other suitable means for holding the stop members which may be of different shape from that described

1275149 Measuring liquid levels electrically DISTILLERS CO (CARBON DIOXIDE) Ltd 8 Dec 1970 [9 Sept 1969] 44524/69 Heading G1N The level of liquid in a tank is measured by a float attached to a hinged arm and to the slides of a potentiometer inside the tank, connected in a bridge circuit outside the tank, whereby the level is determined by the bridge unbalance current. The output signal may be modified to represent mass by introducing compensation for variation in density with liquid level.

column13: 844,611. Power presses; transferring blanks. PRESS EQUIPMENT Ltd. Feb. 15, 1957 [Nov. 16, 1955; Dec. 21, 1955], Nos. 32744/55 and 36586/55. Classes 83 (3) and 83 (4). A press assembly comprises a number of standard individual power-presses mounted sideby-side with their crank-shafts coupled together for synchronized operation, in combination with means for feeding components from one press to the next throughout the assembly. The presses 11, Fig. 1, may be arranged with the axes of the crank-shafts in alignment with a single common drive-shaft, or with their individual shafts connected by flexible joints. The presses are mounted on a common bed-plate 12 with a single bolster-plate 13 extending along the line. Transfer-mechanism comprises a longitudinally-reciprocated bar 18 carrying fingers 19 for gripping the components. In an alternative arrangement, Fig. 4, the axes of the crankshfts 30 are at right-angles to the line, and are connected by gearing. Transfer-mechanism comprises arms with suction gripping-pads carried by bar 33, which is reciprocated by a rod 41 connected by linkage 43-49 to a cam 50 on one of the press crankshafts. Safety-devices may be fitted so that if a pick-up head does not operate, a vacuum-operated switch associated with the head remains closed, and the relevant press-clutch will not engage.

A stacker-reclaimer has a luffing and slewing mounting (2, 4) supporting a boom structure with a main, forwardly extending boom (14) having material-conveying means running along it, and a rearwardly extending tail boom (22) with a counterbalance weight (34) depending from its rear end. The tail boom is at a higher level than the main boom to provide clearance of a feeder conveyor (26) to the material-conveying means. The counterbalance weight is attached by a pivot (30) on the tail boom and is displaceable about the pivot by a control cable (36) attached to a non-luffing part (40) of the luffing and slewing mounting forwards of the luffing axis (6) whereby the weight is displaced forwards in relation to the pivot in upward luffing movements of the boom structure. This compensates for the rearward displacement of the rear end of the tail boom in such movements, and reduces the maximum overturning moment to be resisted in the working luffing range.

A securing device in the form of a bolt or screw or dowel (1 or 1a) comprises a body (2 or 2a) into which a coaxial aperture extends from one end. An intermediate portion of the body through which the aperture extends has a tapering inner wall (14) and is provided with axial slots (16). A tapered pin (20) fitting the wall (14) is force fitted into the aperture to deform the intermediate portion outwards. The slots facilitate the deformation to cause the body to grip the sides of an aperture in which the securing device is inserted. Using such a device in the form of a bolt, the bolt shank can be held in engagement with the sides of the hole through which it passes while the shank is tensioned by the clamping load. Using such a device as a dowel makes it possible to accept a greater tolerance in the intended fit in a dowel hole.
The present invention provides components with metamaterial structures for use in enhanced geothermal systems.

column12: Löschkammerbaugruppe für ein automatisches Transferschaltersystem und Verfahren zu dessen Zusammenbau
column13: Eine Löschkammerbaugruppe zur Verwendung in einem automatischen Transferschalter weist ein Gehäuse auf, das zwei einander gegenüberliegender Seitenwände und eine zwischen den beiden einander gegenüberliegenden Seitenwände angebaute primäre Entionisationsplatte aufweist. Die primäre Entionisationsplatte weist einen Zungenabschnitt auf, der im Wesentlichen mittig zwischen den gegenüberliegenden Seitenwänden ausgerichtet ist und sich zu einer Kontaktbaugruppe hin erstreckt. Der Zungenabschnitt ist so gestaltet, dass er die Unterdrückung eines elektrischen Lichtbogens, der von der Kontaktbaugruppe ausgeht, erleichtert.

column12: Improvements in or relating to machines for closuring bottles or other containers
column13: 710,387. Closuring containers. METAL BOX CO., Ltd. Feb. 20, 1953 [April 28, 1952], No. 10708/52. Class 125 (2) In apparatus of the kind described in Specification 450,093 wherein screw closures are fed on to supports 6 beneath a plunger 7 which descends and rotates to carry the closure thr;ough the supports and apply it to a container, the closures pass by gravity down a shoot 5 having a resilient gate at its exit end and are pushed one at a time past the gate on to the supports 6 by a reciprocating member. As shown in Figs. 1, 2 and 4, a platform 1 is fitted with spaced brackets 2 the tops of which carry bars 3 the front ends of which are attached to the supports 6 and the rear ends of which carry each am inwardly facing U-shaped channel which co-operate to form the shcot 5. The spacing at the brackets 2 iis adjustable to suit different diameters of closure. The resilient gate is formed by spring plungers 13 carried on the shoot, the tension being adjustable by screws 14. A tongue 39 prevents a closure from rising when ejected 'from the shoot. If the gate jams, the closure forces down :a pivoted plate 15 against a spring 17 to allow ejection of the closure. Platform 1 carries spaced guides 23 for a slider 22 carrying a vertical arm 26 pivoted between two lugs 25. Two bars 21 extend forwardly from the arm 26 and carry at their front end a depending fork 18 entering between the two parts of the shoot. Bars 21 are normally urged to the position shown by a spring 32 acting an ,a projection 29 of the arm 26. A lever 35 engages between two rollers 34 carried on the top of arm 26 .and is reciprocated by a cam 38 through links 40, 41, 42. When the lever 35 moves to the right, Fig. 4, it first tilts the arm 26 clockwise against spring 32 to cause the fork 18 to enter the shoot to feed a closure past the resilient gate during advancement of the slider 22. When the lever moves to the left, spring 32 raises the fork to clear the next closure to be fed and then the slider is restored to its lefthand position. A stop 44 normally engages grooves in the guides 23 and in the slider 22 to prevent advancement of the latter but when a container approaches the capping station it actuates a lever 48 which withdraws the stop 44 against spring action to allow the feed of a closure. Altenatively, an approaching container may actuate directly the lever 35. In a modification, Fig. 5, an approaching container actuates am arm 48a to rock a shaft 59 which results in a plate 54 pivoting downwardly about its pivot 55. This causes descent of a rod 50 having a head 18a formed with an inclined susface 49 which enters between the first and second closure in the shoot 5a to feed the former past the resilient gate 11a. The parts are restored by a spring 63.

Class 125 (2) In apparatus for applying screw closures to containers of the kind described in Specification 450,093 in which a closure is held in a chuck 16 which is lowered and turned angularly to apply th closure to the container a sleeve 7 is supportec by the chuck, can move relatively thereto and is formed with an in wardly-extending pro jection to hold the closure in axial alignment with the chuck until it is grippec thereby. As shown ir Fig. 1, the sleeve 7 is suspended by pegs 8 working in slots 9 in the chuck and is urged downwardly by a spring 10. As the head descends, an annular projection 14 on the sleeve engages a bead 15 on the closure 6 to centralize it and, on further descent of the chuck, the sleeve remains stationary to compress the spring 10 until the closure enters the chuck. In a modification, Fig. 2 (not shown), for closures not provided with a bead, spaced projections are provided on the inner wall of the sleeve to engage the top of the closure, the projections working in slots in the chuck.

column12: Vapor deposition process for producing ªß-silicon carbide
column13: 1,128,757. #-Silicon carbide. TEXAS INSTRUMENTS Inc. 5 May, 1966, No. 19961/66. Heading C1A. A layer of #-SiC is produced by introducing a gaseous stream containing Si- and C-bearing compounds and H 2 into a reaction zone containing a heated substrate such that a quiescent zone is established adjacent to the substrate through which the gases diffuse and react to deposit SiC. The product may be stoichiometric, or may have up to 1% excess C or up to 40% excess Si. The substrate, which is heated to 900-1470‹ C., may be a filament of Ta, SiC or graphite, heated by direct passage of electric current using water-cooled electrodes (Fig. 1, not shown), or a graphite crucible, heated by R.F. coils (Fig. 2, not shown). Alternatively, a carbon body with depressions in it may be used, and the carbon subsequently burnt off to give boat-shaped articles. The Si and C source may be in the same compound, e.g. CH 3 SiCl 3 , (CH 3 ) 2 SiCl 2 , (CH 3 ) 3 SiCl or (CH 3 ) 4 Si, or in different compounds, e.g. C from methane, ethane, propane, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethylene, or propylene, and Si from SiCl 4 , SiBr 4 , SiI 4 , mono-, di- or tri-, chloro-, bromo-, or iodo-silane. The mole ratio CH 3 SiCl 3 /H 2 may be 4À2-99.

column12: MATERIAL WITH PROISOTROPIC STRESS RESPONSE STRUCTURE
Air conditioner with condensate slinging fan
column13: An air conditioning system having a fan that moves air over the outside heat exchanger of the system. The fan is of the bladed axial flow type. A winglet projects curvilinearly both radially outward from the trailing end of the tip of each blade of the fan and perpendicularly upward from the blade pressure surface. A conduit directs condensate formed on and dripping from the system inside heat exchanger to a collector located under the fan. The blade winglets scoop condensate from the collector and draw the water inward toward the center of rotation of the fan, where air moving through the fan slings the water on to the outside heat exchanger.

PCT No. PCT/GB93/01511 Sec. 371 Date Mar. 10, 1995 Sec. 102(e) Date Mar. 10, 1995 PCT Filed Jul. 16, 1993 PCT Pub. No. WO94/02545 PCT Pub. Date Feb. 3, 1994.An intumescent composition comprises saline soluble inorganic silicate fibrous material containing CaO, MgO and no more than 4% by weight of Al2O3, such as calcium magnesium silicate. The fibres may be vitreous, with an average length of 10 to 500 microns, and may form 5 to 30 weight percent of the composition. The composition may be incorporated in a coating composition, e.g. for wet coating (paint) or powder coating, or a mastic or putty, or a composition containing a polymer. Enhanced fire protection can be provided, and the coating compositions may be applied as a single thick coating rather than by building up thin layers.

A composition for a neutron radiation (biological) shield in a nuclear reactor (see Group XL(a)) comprises bitumen and a bitumen-soluble boron compound, such as an organic ester of a boric acid, e.g. an alkylene glycol diborate or an alkyl borate, in which the boron content is 0,75-7,5% by weight of the composition. The bitumen may be blown, steam distilled or straight-run from petroleum, or fluxed, preferably with a hydrogen content of at least 10% by weight. Specific boron compounds are trihexylene glycol di-borate, triethylene-, tributylene- and trioctylene-glycol di-borates, and monohydric alcohol borates such as 2, 6, 8-trimethyl-4-nonyl borate. Prior art discloses boron compounds such as the carbide fluoride and oxide, and compositions comprising borated bitumen with a heavy metal or metal compound such as galena or lead shot.

column13: In the production of zirconium tetrachloride by chlorine with a zirconia-silica compound such as zircon, in the presence of an oxygen acceptor, preferably elemental carbon or carbon monoxide, as a fluidised bed, a siliconcontaining additive which reacts exothermically with chlorine is added to sustain the reaction temperature. Ferrosilicon and silicon carbide are particularly suitable, and may be added in amounts from 2 to 50% by weight of the zirconia-silica compound employed. The carbon may be supplied as petroleum coke and the zircon preferably has a particle size of 76 to 250 microns and is present in a zircon-coke ratio of 4 to 1. Reaction temperatures may be from 900 to 1250 DEG C., and the reaction vessel may be provided with a perforated base plate through which the pressure drop is from one half to fifty times the pressure drop across the bed. The chlorine inlets are preferably fitted with covers to prevent solids passing therethrough. According to Examples, (i) a 4 to 1 zircon/coke mixture was preheated to 1100 DEG C. in a fluidised reactor with an air stream. Air was replaced by chlorine and a mixture of zircon, ferrosilicon and coke was thereafter fed continuously whereby the reaction temperature was maintained at 1070-1150 DEG C. Zirconium tetrachloride and silicon tetrachloride were separately condensed. (iii) A bed of zircon sand of average particle size 140 microns was fluidised with air and preheated to 1100 DEG C., after which the air supply was replaced by a mixture of chlorine and carbon monoxide whilst a zircon/ferrosilicon mixture was fed in continuously thereby maintaining the required reaction temperature. Specifications 794,666 and 813,489 are referred to.

column12: Improvements in or relating to the production of articles from synthetic resinous materials
column13: Laminated or composite articles permeated with synthetic resins are produced by impregnating masses of permeable reinforcing material, e.g. asbestos, with synthetic resins, further impregnating one mass with a meta hydroxy phenol and another mass with an aldehyde, bringing the masses into contact so that the aldehyde and phenol will form a resin in both masses and curing the resin. Phenol-, cresol-, and urea-aldehyde resins may be used as the initial impregnant. In an example, two pieces of asbestos felt are impregnated with a partially condensed phenolformaldehyde resin and alcohol; one felt is also impregnated with resorcinol and the other with paraformaldehyde. After adjusting the flexibility by controlled evaporation of alcohol or by spraying with water the pieces of impregnated felt are heated to 100 DEG C. while in contact under pressure. Alternative meta-hydroxy phenols and aldehydes are phloroglucinol and pyrogallol, and furfural and crotonaldehyde respectively.

Titanium dioxide pigment is produced by coating titanium dioxide which may contain zinc or antimony oxides, alumina, silica or sodium or potassium sulphate, phosphate or borate with aluminium oxide, silicon dioxide and zirconium dioxide, and heating the resulting coated pigment to a temperature of at least 625 DEG C., and preferably 700-800 DEG C. The preferred percentages of coatings referred to the weight of the final coated pigment are as follows: aluminium oxide 0.5-5%, silicon dioxide 0.05-5%, zirconium dioxide 0.3-3%. It is preferable to coat the pigmentry titanium dioxide first with aluminium oxide and then zirconium dioxide before coating with the silicon dioxide. A further coating of aluminium oxide subsequent to the aluminium oxide, silicon dioxide and zirconium oxide coatings may be applied and this may be followed by a further coating of silicon dioxide. In the example pigmentary titanium dioxide is coated with zirconium dioxide, aluminium oxide, and silicon dioxide by slurrying the pigmentary titanium oxide in water, adding thereto a solution of zirconium and aluminium sulphates followed by an aqueous solution of sodium silicate. Portions of the resulting pigment were heated to 800 DEG C. and 740 DEG C. respectively. A further portion was not heated for comparison purposes only. The three pigments thus obtained were incorporated in paper which was subsequently impregnated with melamine formaldehyde resin and these papers then formed facings for a phenol formaldehyde bonded paper board. The thus prepared laminates were exposed to the light from an ultraviolet lamp to demonstrate the superior light stability of the pigments according to the invention.ALSO:Titanium dioxide pigment is produced by coating titanium dioxide with aluminium oxide, silicon dioxide and zirconium dioxide, and heating the resulting coated pigment to a temperature of at least 625 DEG C., and preferably 700-800 DEG C. The preferred percentages of coatings referred to the weight of the final coated pigment are as follows: aluminium oxide 0.5-5%, silicon dioxide 0.05-5%, zirconium dioxide 0.3-3%. It is preferable to coat the pigmentary titanium dioxide first with aluminium oxide and then zirconium dioxide before coating with the silicon dioxide. A further coating of aluminium oxide subsequent to the aluminium oxide, silicon dioxide and zirconium oxide coatings may be applied and this may be followed by a further coating of silicon dioxide. In the example pigmentary titanium dioxide is coated with zirconium dioxide, aluminium oxide, and silicon dioxide by slurrying the pigmentary titanium oxide in water, adding thereto a solution of zirconium and aluminium sulphates followed by an aqueous solution of sodium silicate. Portions of the resulting pigment were heated to 800 DEG C and 740 DEG C. respectively. A further portion was not heated for comparison purposes only. The three pigments thus obtained were incorporated in paper which was subsequently impregnated with melamine formaldehyde resin and these papers then formed facings for a phenol formaldehyde bonded paper board. The thus prepared laminates were exposed to the light from an ultraviolet lamp to demonstrate the superior light stability of the pigments according to the invention.ALSO:Pigmented resinous materials are made by mixing a titanium dioxide pigment coated with aluminium oxide, silicon dioxide and zirconium dioxide and heated to at least 625 DEG C. and optionally super coated with a further layer of aluminium oxide and if desired a further coating of silicon dioxide with a thermo setting synthetic resin in the manufacture of which is used a reducing agent for example, a urea formaldehyde, melamine formaldehyde, or phenol formaldehyde resin, and curing the resin. The pigment may be incorporated into a supporting material and the material may subsequently be impregnated with the resin. The pigment may be incorporated into a paper in the final beating stage; one or more of the sheets containing the pigment may then be impregnated with a urea formaldehyde or melamine formaldehyde or phenol formaldehyde resin, the sheets thus produced being then subjected to a temperature of 120-150 DEG C. and a pressure of 2000-2700 lbs per sq. inch whereby the resin is cured. In the example papers containing two pigments according to the invention and one used for comparisons only are impregnated with melamine formaldehyde resin and form the facings of a laminate comprising brown unpigmented craft paper bonded with a phenolic resin. The boards thus produced are irradiated with artificial light of a spectral composition identical to sunlight and the pigments according to the invention show superior light stability.

column12: Improvements in and relating to Kilns.
column13: 5341. Norman, W. A., and Evans, E. April 9. Brick, pottery, and like kilns.-The draught passages in the floor of a ceramic kiln are provided with shrouding-means whereby accumulation of dust and rubbish in and around the passages is prevented and a clear passage for the draught is maintained. Fig. 1 shows the application of the invention to a kiln provided with lower, middle, and upper floors 1, 2, 3. The draught passages 9 in the floor 2 are provided with pipes 10 placed over or around them. The tubes are preferably provided with caps 11 and the upper ends of the pipes 10 may be notched as shown at 12. A modified form of shrouding-means consists of a mushroom cap provided with legs arranged to stand over the hole, or the legs may pass down through the hole and stand on the lower floor. In a further modification, the pipes are arranged to pass through the middle floor and rest on the bottom floor or almost reach it. In the case where the pipes rest on the bottom floor, holes or notches are provided in the pipe. When it is desired to reduce the draught, some of the tubes may he stopped by a plug cap. In the arrangement shown in Fig. 1, the gases from the fire-places 6 pass through the flues 16 into the kiln and thence down through the floor 3, shrouding pipes 10, and outlets 8 in the lower floor to the chimney flue 7.

1,139,140. Reciprocating pumps. DISTILLERS CO. (CARBON DIOXIDE) Ltd. Aug.25, 1967 [Sept. 16, 1966], No.41585/66. Heading F1A. Liquid, e.g. beer, is delivered under pressure from a tank 12 through a valve 14 to a diaphragm pump 1 from which it is discharged through valves 17, 19 to a nozzle 20 by air pressure applied to the pump diaphragm. The valve 14 includes an electric switch which is open when the valve is open and closed when the valve is closed and in circuit with solenoids controlling the valves 8, 19 so that the liquid may only be dispensed after the pump chamber has been charged. The stroke of the diaphragm may be varied by means of concentric and removable rings secured to one side of the diaphragm.

column13: Titanium dioxide is produced by vapour phase oxidation of titanium tetrahalide, particularly tetrachloride, in the presence of a source of thorium. The latter may be provided as a water-soluble thorium salt, e.g. ThCl4, Th (NO3)4nH2O, or as a thorium compound with high vapour pressure below 1000 DEG C., e.g. thorium oxide, hydroxide, carbonate, oxalate, sulphate, phosphate or sulphide, the thorium content of which, in the case of batchwise fluidized bed operation, constitutes 0.01-5% of the bed material, or in the case of continuous bed operation or of the introduction of reactants into an empty chamber constitutes 0.001-10% of the theoretical yield of TiO2. The reaction is carried out autothermally at 800-1400 DEG C. and is initiated by preheating of the reactants, combustion of a fuel in the reactor, or electrical means. A bed of silica, zirconia, alumina, titania, zircon or mixtures thereof may be used, fluidized by the reactant vapours or nitrogen. The reactant vapours may include halides of aluminium, zirconium, silicon, antimony or phosphorus as rutilizing-agents, e.g. mixed aluminium and silicon halides as disclosed in Specification 986,660. The titanium dioxide is recovered directly or passed to a second oxidation zone where it acts as nuclei for further deposition of titania at 600 DEG C. at least (as disclosed in Specification 991,318).

column12: Draft tube for wood burning stoves
column13: A draft tube in a wood burning stove is provided with a nozzle at the lower end thereof for directing a portion of the draft air downwardly against the charge of burning wood, coal, etc. and deflects a portion thereof sideways into a zone above the fuel to provide a more complete combustion of the rising volatiles. The nozzle may be integral with the draft tube or may be attached thereto as an accessory. The nozzle includes a tube having an outside diameter somewhat smaller than the inside diameter of the draft tube to define an annular passage therewith when the nozzle is installed. An annular radial flange is mounted on the outside and at the lower end of the nozzle and in line with the annular clearance whereby the major portion of the air and draft will flow directly downwardly through the nozzle tube while a portion passing through the annular passage will strike the flange and be deflected perpendicularly to the flow of the draft.

1,145,803. Reciprocating pumps. DISTILLERS CO. (CARBON DIOXIDE) Ltd. Sept. 6, 1967 [Sept. 16, 1966], No.41584/66. Heading F1A. Liquid is supplied under pressure from a reservoir to a diaphragm pump chamber 4 having inlet and outlet valves 17, 18 and an electrically actuated dispensing valve 20 electrically connected in circuit with a control switch and an electrically actuated valve 10 in an actuating air supply circuit to the diaphragm. Also in the air circuit is a flow controlled switch 11 in the pressure line and a flow controlled switch 13 in the exhaust line, both switches being in circuit with the actuating means of valves 10, 20. Actuation of the control switch opens valves 20, 10 whereby air is applied to the diaphragm to discharge the liquid. Flow through switch 11 closes the switch to hold the circuit when the control switch is released. When all liquid is discharged air flow ceases and switch 11 opens, valve 20 closes and valve 10 connects the diaphragm air chamber to exhaust through switch 13 which is held open until the diaphragm completes a filling stroke.

column12: DRAFT TUBE FOR WOOD BURNING STOVES
column13: Title - Draft Tube For Wood Burning Stoves A draft tube in a wood burning stove is provided with a nozzle at the lower end thereof for directing a portion of the draft air downwardly against the charge of burning wood, coal, etc. and deflects a portion thereof sideways into a zone above the fuel to provide a more complete combustion of the rising volatiles. The nozzle may be integral with the draft tube or may be attached thereto as an accessory. The nozzle includes a tube having an outside diameter somewhat smaller than the inside diameter of the draft tube to define an annular passage therewith when the nozzle is installed. An annular radial flange is mounted on the outside and at the lower end of the nozzle and in line with the annular clearance whereby the major portion of the air and draft will flow directly downwardly through the nozzle tube while a portion passing through the annular passage will strike the flange and be deflected perpendicularly to the flow of the draft.

In the production of titanium dioxide by vapour phase oxidation of the tetrahalide in a fluidized bed, deposition of TiO2 on the bed particles is reduced by introducing metallic aluminium into the bed, for example as discrete particles, dropped into the bed, as wire or in molten form. Thus fine aluminium particles can be entrained and fed in a chlorine, carbon dioxide, nitrogen or argon stream or colloidal, fume aluminium may be fed mixed with the oxygen stream. The bed material may be withdrawn, cleaned and recycled, as in Specification 919,019, in which case aluminium may be added to the recycled solids. The amount of aluminium may be from 0.1 to 10% or higher. Specification 761,770 also is referred to.

column12: Fuel injection pump for internalcombustion engines
Improvements in or relating to the preparation of titanium dioxide
column13: Titanium dioxide is produced by feeding titanium tetrachloride with an oxygen-containing gas to a fluidized bed of inert material having a particle size of 40 to 1000m and having a nature such that on fluidizing with air at 1000 DEG C. for 100 hours at five times the minimum fluidizing velocity, the entrained fines constitute less than 5 per cent of the material originally present. Suitable materials are silica, alumina, zircon and rutile, which may have been previously chlorinated to remove impurities. The tetrachloride may be fed admixed with the oxygen-containing gas or as a jet of gas or liquid to the perforated plate on which the bed rests or to a point in the fluidized bed. If desired fuel gases such as carbon monoxide may be mixed with the reactants or separately fed to the bed to supply heat, or heat may be supplied from an external source. The temperature of the bed may be from 700-1200 DEG C., preferably 800-950 DEG C. for anastase production and 800-1100 DEG C. for rutile production. The tetrachloride/oxygen ratio may be from 1 : 0.2 to 1 : 5. Specification 724,193 is referred to.

1,267,922. Diaphragm pumps. DISTILLERS CO. (CARBON DIOXIDE) Ltd. May 30, 1969 [May 31, 1968], No. 26097/68. Heading F1A. [Also in Division A4] In a liquid dispense system, carbon dioxide at 27 pressurizes beer in tank 12 and pipe 13 up to combined reed switch and closed valve 14. On depressing one switch button 32 or 33, relays are energized to open a solenoid dispenser valve 30 or 31, close an exhaust valve 10 and open a solenoid valve 8 whereby air-pressure acts on diaphragm pump 5 to displace and dispense a predetermined volume of beer via pipes 15, 18 and check valve 17. When the diaphragm stops, reed switch/valve 14 opens to de-energize relay, closing valve 8 and the operated dispense valve 30 or 31 and opening exhaust valve 10 whereby pressurized beer at 12, 13 passes valve 14 and refils the diaphragm chamber via 15 for dispensing the next volume via either dispense point. On depressing one dispense switch e.g. 32, a relay renders the other 33 inoperative.

Finely divided metal oxides are prepared by introducing into a fluidized bed of particulate material at a temperature of at least 700 DEG C. a first metal halide (not F) and an oxygenating gas and simultaneously introducing at a point higher in the bed a second metal halide. Metals specified are titanium aluminium zirconium. Halide specified:-chloride. Oxygenating gas specified:-air or O2. Particulate size specified:-50-2000 m . The second halide is introduced at a distance above the first so that the first is oxidized before contact with second. The first halide may be a mixture of those specified or may be the same as the second and preferably forms sub-pigmentary particles of oxide. When the first and second halides are the same the amount introduced as the first halide is in the range 5-90% of the whole halide introduced. When they are different the first is in the range 0.5-10% of the total weight of metal oxide produced. The oxygenating gas may be introduced at any point in the bed or mixed with the first metal halide. The second metal halide is added so that it mixes rapidly and uniformly with the products of the first reaction. To the reactants may be added an alkali metal halide (potassium specified), water or silicon halide in the range 0.001-5% of the total weight of metal oxide produced. In an example a bed of particulate TiO2 was heated to 1050 DEG C. and TiCl4, preheated to 200 DEG C. and containing SiCl4 in an amount to give 0.125% silica by weight of the TiO2 produced, was passed in as a first halide. Oxygen preheated to 150 DEG C. and containing AlCl3 to give 0.62% alumina by weight of the TiO2 produced was passed in at the same level. Above these inlets is introduced preheated TiCl4. Good yields of TiO2 in a finely divided state are produced.

column13: A method and apparatus for forming an electric resistance heating coil of desired resistance that involves forming a straight helical coil and centering the formed coil for transfer to a first folding station for holding the straight helical coil into a U-shaped helical coil.

Oxides of titanium, aluminium, zirconium or hafnium are prepared by reacting the corresponding halide with oxygen in the presence of a fluidized bed of inert solids which has a cross-sectional area at least that of a circle of 15 inches diameter and contains sufficient solid to conserve the heat from p the exothermic reaction to render it self-sustaining. The reaction is effected in the bed and the oxide product is for the most part discharged in entrainment with the outgoing gases. The oxide accretion on the bed particles is maintained at or below 20% by weight of the inert solids material. The reactants are introduced, preferably separately, through a plurality of inlet ducts distributed across the bed cross-section and the inlet ducts are provided with constrictions each of which produces a pressure drop which is at least one half of the pressure drop from the bottom to the top of the fluidized bed. The fluidized bed may be as described in Specification 761,770, i.e. the particle size should be from 40-1000 microns, and temperature of the bed is normally between 800 DEG and 1300 DEG C. A proportion of the ozide product forms as an accretion on the bed particles and accordingly a portion of the bed may be withdrawn and cleaned, for example by chlorination. The reactants, namely the halide and oxygen are normally employed in stoichiometric amounts, but oxygen to chloride ratios from 0,75:1 to 4:1 may be employed. Withdrawal of the bed solids may be employed as a cooling means since such solids may be withdrawn and cooled or fed at any temperature desired to obtain adequate cooling and adequate purging of oxide accretion from the bed particles. The apparatus employed is described and claimed in Specification 919,020 and the orifices in the perforated base of the fluidized bed may be provided with means to bar ingress of the bed material to the fluidizing gas supply, as described in Specifications 724,193, 794,666 and 813,489. According to examples (1) a vertical steel shaft furnace was provided with a perforated base fitted with manifolds feeding titanium tetrachloride and oxygen. A zircon sand bed of 150 microns average diameter was preheated to 1100 DEG C. and the reaction temperature was thereafter maintained at 980 DEG C., overheating being prevented by feeding and removing zircon sand. A minor quantity of water may be added to the oxygen reactant stream. (3) Aluminium trichloride and oxygen were separately fed to a fluidized bed of zircon sand which was maintained at 1000 DEG C. throughout the reaction by withdrawing zircon sand and feeding in cool sand. Aluminium oxide of 0,07 microns diameter was obtained. Specification 849,140 also is referred to.

In the recovery of zirconium values as soluble compounds from zirconiferous materials rich in silica, e.g. zircon sand, the finely divided zirconiferous materials are admixed with at least one finely divided alkali metal oxide, hydroxide, or carbonate, and at least one finely divided alkaline earth metal or magnesium oxide, hydroxide, or carbonate, and the mixture is then roasted, under conditions such as substantially to avoid fusion or sintering of the mixture. The amount of alkaline earth metal or magnesium compound employed is preferably in the range of 0,2 to 1,8 stoichiometric equivalents per equivalent of zirconia+silica, and the amount of alkali metal compound is preferably in the range of 0,1 to 1,9 stoichiometric equivalents per equivalent of zirconia+silica. The zirconium values may be recovered from the roasted product by digesting with a mineral acid, preferably in excess, and lixiviating with water, preferably at elevated temperature, to dissolve the zirconium. The digestion with the mineral acid, for example hydrochloric or nitric, preferably sulphuric, acid, is carried out such that the treated material is in the form of a slurry, paste or, preferably, a substantially dry pulverulent mass. Advantageously dilute acid may be added during the lixiviation with water. The mixing prior to roasting is preferably carried out in the dry state for example in a drum with vanes, or it may be mixed as a slurry or paste, and either dried or fed as it is to the roasting, which may be carried out in stationary or moving hearth furnaces either in crucibles or directly, or preferably either in batches or continuously in a rotary furnace in which it undergoes mixing during the roasting. The zirconium sulphate solution obtained when the roast is digested with sulphuric acid may be used for incorporation with titanium dioxide pigments either by neutralizing the solution either in situ or prior to mixing with the titanium dioxide. The thus coated or mixed pigment is then dewatered and dried.

column13: After subjecting a calcined titanium dioxide pigment to a wet treatment, a non-ionic surfactant, e.g. 0.1-0.4%, is added to the pigment before drying. The calcined pigment is obtained by the sulphate process or by the vapour phase oxidation or hydrolysis of a titanium tetrahalide. The wet treatment comprises wetting the pigment with a liquid, e.g. water, to form a dispersion, slurry or paste. The surfactant may be a water-soluble condensation product of ethylene oxide with an alkylated phenol or a long chain fatty alcohol. In an example, a titanium dioxide pigment was produced by precipitation from a sulphate solution using nitrile inducing nuclei and the precipitate was washed, calcined, milled and dispersed in an aqueous slurry with 0.5% sodium silicate, hydro-separated to remove aggregates, dewatered, treated with 0.2% a surfactant, filtered, dried and milled.

column13: Zirconia-silica composites having a particle diameter less than 0.1m and containing at least 1% by weight of silica, are produced by reacting in an inert fluidized bed of particulate material at a temperature of 800-1200 DEG C., an oxygenating gas and a vapourous mixture of zirconium and silicon tetrahalides, the proportion of silicon tetrahalide being at least 1.5% by weight. The term tetrahalides excludes tetrafluorides, and an oxygenating gas is a gas which will oxidize the tetrahalides to the corresponding oxides. The tetrahalide gases may be mixed before passing to the reaction chamber or passed in separately, the oxygenating gas may be added separately or in admixture with one or both of the tetrahalide gases. Oxygen, air or water-vapour are preferably used as oxygenating gases, the proportion of oxygem in the gas being at least stoichiometric relative to the tetrahalide, preferably 1 : 1-5 : 1. Less than 2% of other white oxides, e.g. aluminium, boron, tin, antimony, zinc and phosphorus may also be present in the composite and are prepared from their corresponding halides. Specifications 919,019 and 981,422 are referred to.ALSO:Zirconia-silica composites having a particle diameter less than 0.1m and containing at least 1% by weight of silica are produced by reacting in an inert fluidized bed of particulate material at a temperature of 800-1200 DEG C., an oxygenating gas and a vaporous mixture of zirconium and silicon tetrahalides the proportion of silicon tetrahalide being 1.5-90% by weight. Less than 2% of other white oxides may also be included provided their presence does not affect particle size, for example, aluminium, boron, tin, zinc, antimony and phosphorus prepared from their corresponding halides. The term tetrahalides excludes tetrafluorides and oxygenating gases comprise any gas which will oxidize the halides to the oxides, e.g. oxygen, air, and water-vapour, the oxygen in such gases being at least stoichiometric with respect to the tetrahalide gases preferred ratios being 1 : 1-5 : 1. Specifications 919,019 and 981,142 are referred to.

column13: A shaft furnace for reacting two gases, e.g. metal halides and oxygen, in a fluidized bed of inert solid particles, is provided at its base with separate sets of passageways for the individual reactant gases which fluidize the bed, each passageway containing a constriction such that the pressure drop thereacross is equal to at least half that from bottom to top of the bed when fluidized. The constrictions are preferably in the form of removable discs having a central orifice. The passageways are so arranged in the base that the separate gases intermingle in the bed. The inert solid has a particle size of 40-1000m and the furnace has a diameter of at least 15 inches. Specific reference is made to the production of titanium dioxide from titanium tetrachloride and oxygen and aluminium trioxide from aluminium trichloride and oxygen according to the process described and claimed in Specification 919,019, Fig. 1 shows furnace 1 having a heat insulating base through which the fluidizing reactant gases pass via manifolds 25 and 26 to two sets of passageways 312, 212 and 112, each containing constriction plates 43. The bulk of the product formed is entrained in the effluent gases which pass out through <PICT:0919020/III/1> port 126. Further bed material is supplied from solids feed device 71 through flanged pipe 70 and surplus is removed through conduit 170 into vessel 81. Fig. 5 shows refractory tubes 400 having downwardly sloping outlets 410 fitted into the passageways of base 11. The gases are supplied through inlets 406,407 into windboxes 404,405 and thence through screw plugs 402 which contain orifice constrictions 403. Specifications 724,193, 761,770, 794,666 and 813,489 also are referred to.

column13: Silicon halides (excluding silicon fluoride) are produced by reacting finely divided silica or silica-bearing materials in suspension in a molten alkali metal or alkaline earth metal halide with a halogen gas in the presence of an oxygen acceptor, preferably carbon or carbon monoxide. Phosgene may be used as oxygen acceptor and halogen. Silica, e.g. zircon or spent bauxite clay containing at least 25% wt. SiO2, and of particle size 76-1000m , is suspended in a molten halide bath in which the halide is preferably the same as the halogen gas employed. The carbon may be coke, graphite or anthracite having a particle size 50m to 2 inches and usually at least twice the average size of the silica employed. The reaction in the presence of carbon, which may be added before or during reaction with the halogen, is generally assisted by external heating, electric induction heating or by the heat produced by the addition of O2 to react with the carbon. Carbon monoxide, which may be added at the same time e.g. in admixture with, the halogen supplied to the melt, causes an exothenuic reaction and the process proceeds autothermally. Reaction temperatures below 1100 DEG C. e.g. 600 DEG -1000 DEG C. may be employed. In order to accelerate the reaction in the presence of carbon, boron or boron compounds e.g. boron halides or boron compounds which react with the halogen in situ to produce boron halides, for example, boron carbides, ferro-boron, anhydrous boric oxide or metal borides e.g. alkali metal or alkaline earth metal borates especially borax, may be incorporated as catalysts in the melt. Preferably such catalysts are halides of the same halogen as the halogen gas employed, are volatile e.g. Bcl3, and are added to the melt in the halogen gas. The boron halides may be recovered from the reaction products and recycled. Specification 864,538 is referred to.

Improvements in or relating to the feeding of sheets of material to machines
column13: 911,047. Feeding sheets. THOMPSON & CO. Ltd., R. D. H. Aug. 26, 1960 [May 27, 1959], No. 18116/59. Class 100 (1). Apparatus for feeding sheets of material to a machine comprises means for feeding the sheets 4 into a pile from underneath the pile, a plate 6 spaced above the pile, a back lay 8 transverse to and adjacent to one end of the plate, means for blowing gas streams on to the underside of the plate 6 so as to blow the topmost sheets of the pile against the back lay 3 and to hold them in a state of suspension, floating and separate from one another, and means for engaging the floating sheets and feeding them one at a time towards the machine. Feeding belts 2 run up an inclined ramp 1 at the upper end of which is a vertical wall 3. The pile of sheets is disposed between the wall 3 and the back lay 8. Rollers 10 are mounted at the lower end of the back lay. A drum 11 having rubber suckers 12 located around its periphery is mounted above the plate 6, the suckers 12 projecting through a hole 7 in the plate when the drum is rotated. As each sucker passes through the hole 7 it is connected, via a hollow shaft upon which the drum is mounted, with a source of suction. At the front end of the pile a horizontal pipe 18 having nozzles 19 is mounted. During operation, compressed-air is blown continuously through the nozzles 19 whereby the top sheets of the pile are separated from one another and are held suspended in the air streams. As the drum 11 rotates the suckers 12 engage the topmost floating sheet and move it horizontally into the nip of feed rollers 24. Feeding belts 2 are driven intermittently and are started by a change in a predetermined capacity between two capacity heads 21, 23, such capacity varying in accordance with the number of sheets disposed between the plate 6 and the ramp 1. The pile of sheets is thus replenished as it becomes depleted by fresh sheets fed to the bottom thereof by the belts 2.

Methods for the production of titanium tetrachloride
Improvements relating to methods for the production of titanium tetrachloride
column13: A mixture of carbon and titanium-bearing material, e.g. rutile, is treated as a fluidized bed, e.g. at 500 DEG -1,000 DEG C., with chlorine or chlorine-containing gases under such conditions that titanium tetrachloride and chlorides of impurities, including ferric chloride, are volatilized and simultaneously removed. A suitable apparatus comprises a furnace at the bottom of which is introduced initially air or oxygen and subsequently chlorine gas. The chlorine reacts with a finely ground heated mixture of titanium ore and powdered carbon which is introduced at the top of the furnace. A continuous process is maintained by volatilizing all ore-impurities in addition to the titanium as their respective chlorides so that the composition of the reaction mixture remains constant. The volatile chlorides and a small proportion of very fine solid particles are passed to the base of a column which is fitted at the top with a reflux condenser and at the bottom with a reboiler containing titanium tetrachloride. A small proportion of the condensed titanium tetrachloride is taken off continuously from the condenser and purified. The remainder is returned down the column where it condenses uprising gases and carries condensed chloride impurities &c. down to the reboiler. Solids are removed from the reboiler as a slurry from which titanium tetrachloride is recovered. Specification 29227/49 (as open to inspection under Section 91) is referred to.

Titanium ores containing iron are treated with sulphur (elemental or combined) at elevated temperatures and the resulting mixture may be leached with mineral acid to remove iron sulphide. The process is carried out using dispersed preferably fluidized material in an atmosphere of oxygen or oxygen and an inert gas. The material may be ground before treating in the fluidized bed which may be partially made up of fine inert particulate material and to which a portion of the product may be returned. The fluidized bed may be heated externally and part of the heat is supplied by burning some of the sulphur in oxygen. Waste sulphuric acid may be used in the leaching process wherein ferrous sulphate is produced and may be recovered. Sulphur and sulphur dioxide are recovered from the heating process which at preferably 600 DEG C. and above is hot enough to vaporize the sulphur. Excess sulphur is used and may be obtained from hydrogen sulphide or iron pyrites as well as elemental sulphur. The sulphur and oxygen containing gases may be preheated before passing into the fluidized bed which may be a batch or continuous process. The acid leaching is preferably carried out using 15-25% acid at 60-85 DEG C.

column13: 1,170,540. Current measuring. MULLARD Ltd. July 18, 1968 [Aug. 17, 1967], No.37871/67. Headings G1A and G1U. In a system for measuring current on a high voltage conductor C by using the Faraday effect, interference effects caused by current in an adjacent conductor TC are reduced by using two spaced Faraday effect bodies Y1, Y2 spaced in the field of the current to be measured, a plane polarized infrared beam being passed through the two bodies in turn in such a direction that the effects on the two bodies of the field due to the adjacent current effectively cancel. In one system infrared light is directed via a fibre optic FO1 to a polariser P1 through one body Y1 and is then reflected by two mirrors (to give 360 degrees phase change) through the second body Y2 analyser P2, fibre optic FO2 to a detector D. The current being measued may be a very high A. C. which will result in a modulated output from the detector which must be demodulated. Alternatively A.C. may be measured, in which case the effect of attenuation in the light path is reduced by inserting a further body to which a reference A. C. is applied and determining the depth of modulation at the detector, which represents the ratio of the reference A.C. to the unknown D.C. In alternative arrangements, both Faraday bodies may be between the conductors C and IC Fig. 3 (not shown) and the system of mirrors M1, M2 may be replaced by a U-shaped light guide Fig. 5 (not shown), a further analyser and polarizer being inserted in the light path since such a guide will cause the loss of any polarization information in the light passing into it. The provisional Specification describes an arrangement using any one magneto optic body set in a magnetic shield surrounding the test conductor to reduce external interference effects.

column13: 3115. Back, A. C. L., and Evans, W. Feb. 11. Gas and explosive-vapour engines.-An oil valve C' is carried on the stem of the main admission valve C. The oil impinges against a spreader C<3>, and mixes with air entering through apertures A<4> in the funnel-shaped chamber F and in the chamber A. The valves C, C' are closed by a spring J, and the oil and air valves E<1>, G' by a handle H. column12: Improvements relating to methods for the production of titanium tetrachloride
column13: Titanium-bearing material is subjected to fluidized-bed chlorination in admixture with carbon, coke or anthracite by means of an upflowing stream of chlorine or a gas mixture containing it. The fluidized bed is supported on a plate having perforations fitted with insert members defining orifices of reduced diameter. Titanium tetrachloride together with ferric chloride and other contaminating chlorides are simultaneously formed and removed together as a single gaseous mixture whilst the less readily chlorinated constituents accumulate in the bed from which they are periodically or continuously removed. The ore feed is preferably of 80-180 micron size whilst that of the carbon or coke is approximately twice this size. The gases enter the furnace at 2-50 times the minimum fluidizing velocity and the reaction temperature is maintained within the range of 500-1000 DEG C. According to an example the bed was formed of 1 part powdered coke and 4 parts of rutile sand which contained 1.2% of zircon. The bed was initially fluidized by admitting air and heating with a gas flame to 900 DEG C., after which air was cut off and chlorine fed at 15 DEG C. The bed was supported upon a perforated plate, the pressure drop across which was 3 1/2 lbs./square inch, and slightly less than the pressure drop across the bed. Titanium tetrachloride was fed through the top of the reaction vessel in a solid stream which fell into and, by evaporation, cooled the bed and maintained the temperature at 870 DEG C. The zircon content of the bed built up to 40% after which air flow replaced chlorine and a portion of the bed was removed through a port in the side of the reactor. Fresh rutile and coke was then added and chlorination continued.

column13: 17,606. Evans, A. F., and Wilson, R. P. Aug. 1, 1912, [Convention date]. Starting ; reversing.- In hydraulic valve-gear of the type having a camactuated plunger and a piston on the valve stem, an auxiliary plunger V is provided, acted upon by the starting-air, to open the valve if the engine has stopped with the camactuated plunger in its inward position, as shown. The gear is shown applied to the starting-valve, and a port b is provided in the auxiliary cylinder U. through which fl ui d escapes when the starting-air is turned off and the piston V occupies its uttermost position. A similar port a in the cylinder G allows escape of fluid if the piston V descends while the piston D is in its outer position. Similar gear is provided for the valves for normal running, but in these cases, the port b is omitted. Duplicate gear is provided for backward starting and running, and the action of the valves is controlled by a number of three way cocks, all of which may be worked together.

Spring catches 23 may be provided to bear against the side plates of the mower and retain the device in raised position.

column13: A linearly adjustable device comprising a main body including at least two body sections each having a longitudinal axis, and a linear actuator. The sections are operatively connected together for linear movement relative to one another in the axial direction. The linear actuator is operatively mounted to the main body for causing the relative axial movement between the body section. The linear actuator includes a drive and a power transmission mechanism operatively connected to the drive. The transmission mechanism includes an elongated threaded member operatively connected to one of the body sections and a cooperating threaded member operatively connected to another of the body sections such that relative rotation between the elongated threaded member and the cooperating threaded member causes relative movement of the body sections.

column13: A distillation probe includes a conduit having a central axis. In addition, the distillation probe includes a baffle assembly disposed in the conduit. The baffle assembly includes a plurality of axially-spaced baffles positioned one-above-the-other in a stack within the conduit. Each baffle has a central axis and a radially outer surface. Each baffle includes a first recess disposed along the radially outer surface of the baffle and extending axially through the baffle. Further, each baffle includes a plurality of cooling conduits mounted to the conduit and positioned radially adjacent the conduit. The cooling conduits are configured to cool the conduit and the baffles.

column12: Solutions of titanium and aluminium sulphuric acid salts
column13: An aqueous solution containing water-soluble sulphuric acid salts of aluminium and titanium which may be employed for coating pigments is prepared by dissolving titanium dioxide in excess sulphuric acid of at least 75% H2SO4 concentration and thereafter adding hydrated alumina to the solution at a temperature of at least 100 DEG C. to reduce the excess acidity. The excess acid employed is at least 90% in excess of the amount required to form titanyl sulphate and the alumina addition is such that the amount of such excess is reduced to 0 to 80%. The titanium/aluminium ration, on an oxide basis, is preferably from 1:0,5 to 1:4. Thus titanium dioxide in the form of the finished pigment or as a pigment intermediate product may be dissolved in 95-97% sulphuric acid in the proportion from 2-13 mols. of sulphuric acid per mol of titanium dioxide at a temperature of 140-150 DEG C., the temperature being maintained by steam heating. Hydrated alumina may then be added at a 100-160 DEG C., after which the reaction medium is diluted with water to a concentration of 20-100 grams/litre of TiO2 and the solids residue separated by decanting or filtering. The final solution obtained may be employed to coat other pigments such as titanium dioxide, or titanates, or composite pigments such as titanium dioxide in admixture with barium sulphate or carbonate, or in admixture with zinc oxide. In such a case, after the solution has been mixed with the pigment, an acid binding substance such as the alkali, metal alkaline earth metal, magnesium and ammonium hydroxides, oxides or carbonate or organic bases are added. Alternatively the addition of the solution to the pigment to be treated may be effected in the presence of the acid binding agent.

column12: Real-time optical filtering method with improved filtered image detection and bandwidth adjustment
column13: In a system for real-time coherent optical filtering of visual imagery which encompasses a laser and a set of lenses for transmitting a visual target image of an input, a Fabry-Perot interferometer for filtering the target image to produce a filtered target image at an output having a predetermined bandwidth of spatial frequency information, the improvements relate to the output being in the form of a low-light level video system capable of detecting the filtered image even when at a low level of luminance, and a laser adjustable in operating power between low and high levels and in operating wavelength within a wide range for adjusting the bandwidths of the interferometer between narrow and broad ranges.

column12: Apparatus for separating and contacting friable particulate organic matter from and with liquids
column13: The invention is concerned with the treatment of friable particulate organic matter such as cottage cheese curd or casein with liquids as by separation of the matter from the liquid in which it may be formed (e.g. whey) and further contacting with a liquid (e.g. a wash liquid such as water), the apparatus being designed to minimize break up of particles into "fines". This is achieved by providing an even non-turbulent flow of friable matter through a series of liquid contacting and separation zones. The separation of the friable matter from liquid is effected on perforate concave screens the perforations of which have outlets larger than their inlets, each screen being disposed in a generally downward direction immediately following a contacting zone in the form of a trough, each screen feeding separated matter into the next trough. The first trough may be solely the deceleration of the liquid.

column13: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF WATER QUALITY A supply of water is continuously monitored to ensure purity by dividing the supply into a number of parallel streams and flowing each through a fish tank containing a fish (or other aquatic animal), the health of each fish being monitored by electrodes in each respective tank. The fish tanks are located together in a main tank and the water supply is drawn from a header tank via pipework, the tank being fed from supply. The apparatus includes an electronic system to monitor the activity of the fish.

column12: Improvements in or relating to the covering of books
column13: 943,438. Bookbinding; feeding sheets. R. D. H. THOMPSON & CO. Ltd. Oct. 26, 1962 [July 28, 1961], No. 27539/61. Headings B6A and B6B. Bookbinding.-A method of applying a back or cover to a book by means of a heat-sealable adhesive interposed between end papers or end pages of the book and the back, includes the steps of feeding the book in an upright position with the spine uppermost, opening out the end papers or end pages so that they form a substantial T-shape with the book body, the papers or pages forming the top arm of the T, positioning a back in register with the end papers or pages, spot-sealing the latter to the back, and then completing the heat-sealing operation of the back to the end papers. As described, the machine is for covering a diary with a soft cover, but it can be used for hard-backed books with round or square spines, in which case the spotsealing operation may be carried out with the end papers and backs lying at an angle of 45 degrees to the vertical. The plan view of Fig. 1 shows operation stations 1 to 6, stations 2, 3, 5, and 6 each being formed from two mirrorimage halves located one on each side of a centre-line XX but only one half of each being shown. At station 1 a stack of uncovered diaries with spines uppermost is placed between side walls to rest on feed tapes 8 which are driven intermittently in the direction. C. The foremost diary is ejected lengthwise in the direction I by a pusher to station 2 where the thickness is checked by side bars which act as a brake, and operate a microswitch to stop the machine if the diary is too thick. Compressed air is directed from below and at each end of the diary to blow upwardly the end papers or pages, and opposed suction pads 10 engage the end papers and open them to lie at 45 degrees to the diary body. The diary body is then gripped by opposed grippers 14, Fig. 12, and carried to station 3, the end papers moving over fixed ploughs 63 which raise the papers to make an angle of 90 degrees to the diary body 65. A rubber pad 68 on an arm 67 bears on, and breaks the stiffness of, the diary spine during the passage through station 3. The grippers 14 return to station 2, and another set, which have returned from station 5, grip and transfer the diary to station 5 where side plates 26 support the end papers at right angles to the diary, and a back or cover is placed thereover. The cover is transferred from a table 29 by an arm 27, pivoted at 28, and both the diary and the cover are registered at the front and rear by jogger plates 70, 72 operated by a shaft 31. The end papers and cover are also registered at the sides by channel-shaped members and bars secured to slidable blocks 42, Fig. 12, and the cover and end papers are bowed upwardly. In this condition, silicone-rubber pads 47 on arms 48 descend on each side of the diary, and heatspotting blocks 49 rise through apertures in the plates 26 and press the cover and end papers against the pads 47. The blocks 42, pads 47, and blocks 49 are actuated, respectively, by arms 50, 52 and 53, each provided with adjusting means. Since either the end papers or the inside of the cover has been previously coated with a dried heat-sealable adhesive, the cover and end papers are thus spot-welded together. A set of grippers 14 now transfers the covered diary to station 6 where the end papers and attached cover fall from the T-position to a 45- degree position to lie over heated platens 120, Fig. 12, and silicone-rubber pads 121 descend to press the cover sides on to the platens to completely heat-seal them to the end papers. Each pad 121 is adjustable by screws 126, and carried by a slide 122 which is reciprocated in a frame 123 by toggle link means 124 and a pusher rod 125. As described, there are three stations 6 to ensure complete heat-sealing, and in each succeeding station the platens 120 are raised by a small amount so as to engage more closely between the diary body and end papers as close to the spine as possible. At station 4 the covers or backs are stacked on edge in a trough and are urged in the direction D against a front stop by two tapes 55 which are driven intermittently. As shown in Fig. 13, covers 83 are separated sequentially from the stack by telescopic sucker arms 80, and placed on a table 29. If the diary cover 83 has a pencil loop in the spine, slidable sections 100 of the table 29 move inwardly to form the loop, and pairs of grippers operated by a pneumatic device 104, 105 close over the loop and preform it. The cover is subsequently fed from table 29 to station 5 by the swinging arm 27. The diaries are moved through stations 2, 3, 5 and 6 by the opposed sets of grippers 14, Fig. 12, which grip a diary at one station, feed it to the next, and then return to the former station. Each gripper arm is pivoted on a split block 23 secured on a shaft 24 which is rocked and also reciprocated lengthwise of the machine in guides 39. The mechanisms may be operated by motor driven camshafts, or a series of hydraulic cylinder and ram assemblies. Feeding sheets.-Sheet-separators. The book covers 83, Fig. 13, are stacked on edge between side channels 56, Fig. 1, and are urged against a front stop-plate by a pair of intermittentlydriven belts 55 on which they rest. Each cover is separated by one or more telescopic sucker arms 80 pivoted at 81, each arm having a follower 86 urged against a cam 84 having a reduced section 87. The suckers 82 withdraw a cover 83 when the followers engage the section- 87, and both the arms 80 and the cam 84 are rotated together until the arms are vertical, whereupon the arms stop, the followers ride out of the section 87 to lower the cover on the table 29, and the cover is then released by the suckers. Feed tables; sheet forwarders. The feed table 29 is provided with two small holes 88 connected by pipes to a source of vacuum to retain the flat cover 83 in position 89, Fig. 1, and the cover is transferred to a second position 95 on the table which also has two suction holes 88: from this second position, the cover is carried by the pivoted oscillating gripper 27 and placed over a book filler. The means for moving the cover from position 89 to position 95 on the table 29 comprises guides 90, Fig. 13, at the side of the table slidably supporting a carrier arm 91 on which are suction heads 94, the arm 91 being pivotal about a shaft 92 to enable a cover to be picked up. Registering. As shown in the right hand half of Fig. 12, the book filler 65 has its. end papers raised to a horizontal position and supported by side plates 26 to receive a cover, which is in a flat condition. Pivoted jogger plates 70, Fig. 10, are swung by shafts 31 to register the book cover 71 fore and aft, and a cranked arm 72, secured to each jogger and adjustable relative thereto by a screw 74, registers the book filler 65. Side register of the cover and extended end papers is also effected by joggers. A phosphorbronze channel-shaped strip which engages each side edge of the end paper is carried by a block 42 slidable towards and away from the book, and a further block 44 on the block 42 carries an adjustable jogger 46 which engages the cover.

Improvements in or relating to the production of titanium tetrahalides
column13: 745,051. Electrolytic production of titanium tetrahalides. BRITISH TITAN PRODUCTS CO., Ltd. June 29, 1953 [July 16, 1952], No. 17971/52. Class 41. Titanium tetrahalide is prepared by electrolysis of a fused metal halide salt bath in which the anode comprises a mixture of titanium compounds, containing at least 90 per cent titanium dioxide, and carbon, the halogen liberated at the anode reacting with the titanium dioxide to form titanium tetrahalide. The fused salt may be potassium chloride, bromide, iodide or fluoride, sodium chloride, bromide, iodide or fluoride, calcium chloride or magnesium chloride, or a mixture of two or more of these, preferably having the same halogen radical. The electrolysis may be carried out in a bath heated to 700 to 1400 C., using a tantalum, graphite or iron cathode, or a liquid cathode of zinc or cadmium. The anode and cathode may be separated by a diaphragm, such as a porous pot, or by a non-porous barrier immersed below the electrolyte surface. The titanium compound may be a synthetic oxide or a natural oxide such as mineral rutile, mineral brookite, or mineral anatase, and may be mixed with charcoal or coal. The mixture may be contained in a porous pot with a carbon rod inserted therein, or the mixture may be bonded with gum, pitch or glue and a carbon rod inserted into the mass; the mixture may also be made into a paste with glycerine or dehydrated castor oil, shaped, dried and baked, with or without a carbon core, or the paste may be fed on the top surface of a decaying anode which is progressivelv lowered into the bath. The titanium tetrahalide gases, such as titanium tetrachloride, are withdrawn from above the anode, with carbon monoxide and dioxide, and condensed.

column13: 908,586. Axial flow fans. WILMOTBREEDEN Ltd. April 12, 1961 [April 13, 1960], No. 13148/60. Class 110 (1). A fan has a hub portion formed with a hollow boss which receives the end of a shaft on which the fan is mounted and blades each having an integrally formed rib extending at least partway along the length of the blade and into the hub. The interior of the boss provides a location for a spigot on the fan shaft and fixing holes 14 are provided in the hub. The fan may be formed from one piece of sheet metal or from two or more pieces 15, 16 as shown in Fig. 3. Hollow bosses 17 on each member may nest together or the base of one boss may be removed as in Fig. 4. In a further embodiment, Fig. 5 (not shown), one piece has three blades and the other piece two blades, the blades being unequally spaced on assembly. Alternatively, the fan is again formed in two pieces, one piece having all the blades extending ' from a central portion and the other having tongues, which are spot welded to the blades, extending from a central portion. The former piece is formed with the hollow boss.

Improvements in or relating to hydraulic dynamometers or brakes
column13: 979,704. Hydraulic rotary absorption dynamometer. HEENAN & FROUDE Ltd. May 31, 1961 [June 1, 1960], No. 19465/60. Heading G1W. A dynamometer 1, particularly for testing brake-horsepower of an aero engine to which it is coupled, has a water inlet control 5 (coupled to the engine throttle) and an outlet 2 the back pressure on which is variable, so as to vary the braking torque, by movement of a valve member 8 carried on a spindle 9. The latter is formed with a piston, 11, sliding in a cylinder 10. Oil is supplied on one side of the piston, through a pipe 39 from a constant speed pump 37 driven independently by an electric motor 80, at a fixed "reference pressure", and on the other side through a pipe 32 from a pump 30 driven by the dynamometer. Thus, movement of the piston, and hence valve member 8, towards the left, will only occur for high engine speeds giving sufficient pressure in pump 30 to overcome the reference pressure. Once this speed has been reached, movement of the valve member 8 causes large increases of back pressure in the outlet 2 for small speed increments, as indicated by the curve ofe in Fig. 36 showing the brake horsepower developed as a function of engine speed. The characteristic of the dynamometer is adjusted by means of coarse and fine needle valves, 40 and 41, arranged in parallel in pipe 34 which communicates, via cylinder 10, with pipe 32, and a needle valve 51 in the reference pressure circuit. These valves may be remotely controlled by means of motors 42, 43, 52. Relief valves are indicated by 48 and 57. Oil for the pumps is obtained from a steadytemperature tank 29. This is positioned to supply a low-pressure fluid head directly to a fluid dashpot 104 for a piston 100 of the spindle 9. Bellows 12 on spindle 9 prevent oil leakage. To simulate different flight conditions, when a variable pitch propeller is to be used, the "coarse pitch" and "fine pitch" oil outlets of the hydraulic propeller control unit of the engine are connected, respectively, to cylinders 27 and 27a of a differentialpressure ram unit 22 (see Figs. 1 and 2) coupled via a lever 18 to the spindle 9. Movement of the valve member 8 will thus be influenced additionally by adjustment of the propeller control unit, or only by the latter if the needle valves 40, 41 and 51 are adjusted to "zero" resistance.

column12: Improvements in or relating to apparatus for detecting cracks in metallic structures
column13: 662,169. Magnetic tests. MINISTER OF SUPPLY. Jan. 18, 1950 [March 2, 1949], No. 5745/49. Class 37. [Also in Group XXXV] Apparatus for detecting flaws in a ferromagnetic cylinder 1, Figs. 1 and 2, comprises a magnet 4, 5, 6 supported in a carriage 12, 13 which is supported by wheels 8, 9, 10, 11 set at an angle so that as the cylinder is rotated, the magnet moves longitudinally of the cylinder; the cylinder is thus magnetically scanned and variations in the local field are detected by any suitable means. In one mode, a tray 14 contains a fluid having a suspension of magnetic powder, so that the cylinder passes through the fluid and the magnetic powder collects along the line of cracks or flaws. A suitable fluid is paraffin or a solution celluloid in acetone, and a suitable powder is iron oxide. In another mode, the tray 14 is replaced by a coil of fine wire, the induced currents being measured. In a final mode, a galvanometer co-operates with an electromagnetic pick-up whose output can be recorded on a cathode-ray oscillograph.

column13: A tippling installation for the discharge of bulk goods from large barges comprises a dry basin (2) in which a trough-shaped cradle (12) can have its ends sealed against opposite end walls (4) of the basin in which there are lock gates (24). The cradle provides a holding vessel into which the barges can be floated through the lock gates. After closing the gates and draining the cradle, the barge is tipped by rolling the cradle sideways along guide and support tracks (34) while the barge is held clamped in the cradle. The contents of the barge are discharged into a receiving space (10) from which any liquid is drained to separate it from the discharged solids that are then collected. The arrangement is able to prevent pollution of the waterway be the escape of any of the barge contents during discharge and it is able to handle-very large barges because they roll on fixed supports relatively little lifting effort needs to be expended.

A linearly adjustable device comprising a main body including at least two body sections each having a longitudinal axis, and a linear actuator.
