Improvements in or relating to the production of metallic halides
column13: 864,538. Metal halides prepared electrolytically. BRITISH TITAN PRODUCTS CO. Ltd. Oct. 31, 1958 [Nov. 27, 1957], No. 37034/57. Class 41. In a process for making halides of tetravalent metals and silicon electrolytically, in which the electrolyte consists of molten alkali metal or alkaline earth metal halide, the anode consists of carbon mixed with the oxide of silica or the metal with which halogen formed at the anode combines to form the tetra halide. The process applies particularly to silica used in the form of quartz, tridymite or siliceous material, e.g. zircon silicates, or bauxite, but zircon dioxide as baddelyite is also specified. This may be finely ground with petroleum coke or charcoal, a binder, e.g. gum, pitch, glycerine or de, hydrated castor oil, compressed to form a rod which is then fired. Alternatively the powdered siliceous material is filled into a porous pot with a carbon rod inserted therein. In a suitable apparatus, molten MgCl 2 , 2, is contained in a vessel 1 provided with a carbon or tungsten cathode 5, and a carbon rod anode 21 immersed in a mixture of carbon and silica 8 surrounded by a silica tube 9. The electrolyte is maintained at 700‹ to 1400‹ C. using a thermocouple 4, and an inert gas fed into a tube 13 carries off the SiCl 4 produced to an outlet 14. Magnesium metal is deposited on the cathode, and forms a pool under the molten MgCl 2 . As the anode is consumed, additions are made of a pasty mixture of carbon, siliceous material and binder, which is baked in the cell. The anode mixture contains about 30% of carbon. Other electrolytes used are CaCl 2 , NaCl and KCl mixture, LiCl, and BeCl 2 . Specifications 745,051, 763,931 and 796,735 are referred to.

column13: 1,093,442. Mixing powders and gases. BRITISH TITAN PRODUCTS CO. Ltd. Feb. 10, 1966 [Feb. 15, 1965], No. 6380/65. Heading B1C. [Also in Division B8] In a process and apparatus for making a lean suspension of a constant proportion of a powder in a gas, the gas is fed into the mass 2 of the powder with velocity sufficient to break down agglomerations and fluidize it. A proportion of the suspension thus formed passes into the outlet duct 10, 9 while the remainder passes through the filter 6 where the powder is trapped and returned to the mass; the filtered gas is added to the suspension in the outlet duct 9 through the slots 11. The leanness of the suspension is controlled by the ratio of the area of the filter 6 to the mouth 10 of the outlet duct, and by bleeding off part of the filtered gas at 12. The upper portion of the chamber is of reduced diameter to increase turbulence.

Electrodes for continuous monitoring water quality
column13: The activity of fish or other aquatic animals used to monitor the purity of a supply of water is detected by sensing the electric potentials generated by respiration or heart beat using silver and silver chloride sintered electrodes encapsulated in a flat insulating cover 46. The water is continuously monitored by dividing the supply into a number of parallel streams and flowing each through a tank 14a containing a fish (or other aquatic animal), the health of each fish being monitored by electrodes in each respective tank. The fish tanks are located together in a main tank (12, Fig. 1) and the water supply is drawn from a header tank (16) via pipework (24), the tank (16) being fed from a supply (18). <IMAGE>

column12: New or improved control for power presses and other machines
column13: 800,223. Machinery guards. PRESS GUARDS, Ltd. March 16, 1956 [March 16, 1955], No. 7625/55. Class 80 (4). In a mechanical or fluid-pressure press, or other machine, which is caused to make a single operative stroke by the automatic actuation of a clutch, valve or other means when a poweroperated guard completes its closing movement, a control mechanism is provided whereby the guard-closing means is energized automatically at regular and predetermined time intervals. In the control mechanism shown in Fig. 1 the guard (not shown) is closed by an air cylinder (not shown) connected through a pipe line G to an air supply union 26 through a valve 25 which is opened by a cam 34 on a crosshead 17 reciprocable on rods 18. The crosshead 17 is actuated by a piston in a cylinder 10 whose opposite ends are alternately supplied with air by a reversing valve 22. The valve 22 is actuated by air pressure through a reducing connector 27 and pilot valves 20, 21 which are alternately opened by pegs 19 on the crosshead 17. The crosshead 17 is coupled to a piston in an oil cylinder 13 connected to an oil reservoir 16 through one-way restrictor valves 14 adjustment of which varies the speed of the crosshead 17 and so varies the time interval between successive actuations of the guard-opening valve 25. The cam 23 is of wedge shape and is transversely adjustable to vary the period during which the valve 25 is held open. The valves 20, 21 may be replaced by limit switches controlling a solenoid or solenoids actuating the valve 22. Alternatively the valves 20, 21 may be replaced by a single double-acting valve, which may be operated through a throw-over spring toggle device. The guard may be locked in the closed position by a lever coacting with a cam on the press crankshaft, the lock being released as the crankshaft passes bottom dead-centre, or as it reaches top dead-centre. The control mechanism is mounted on a bracket 28 for fitting to an existing press, and may control a number of presses. In modifications, a guard-closing air valve is intermittently opened by a cam driven through hydraulic or other variable speed gear by an electric motor, or by a press flywheel. In the control mechanism shown in Fig. 5, an air supply pipe 40 is connected through a guardclosing valve 42 and emergency stop valve 52 to a guard-closing cylinder (not shown), and is also connected through a reducing valve 44 to a valve 45 actuated by a cam on a press crankshaft, or a cam on the press slide. In the top dead-centre position shown the valve 45 is closed and air is supplied through valve 42 to close the guard and start the press. As the crankshaft rotates the valve 45 is opened to admit air to the upper end of a cylinder 49 whose piston 50 is thus depressed and closes valve 42, oil below the piston 50 being moved freely past a one-way restrictor 51 into a reservoir 41. At the completion of a press stroke the valve 45 is closed and air pressure in the oil reservoir 41 slowly raises the piston 50 to reopen valve 42 and start another cycle after a time interval determined by the adjustable oneway restrictor 51. In a modification a guardclosing valve 61, Fig. 6, supplying air to a guardclosing cylinder through an emergency stop valve 62, is opened by a head 63 on the rod of a piston 64 in a cylinder 65 whose lower end is connected to the air supply and whose upper end is connected to an oil reservoir 67 through a one-way adjustable restrictor 66 restricting oil flow towards the reservoir. The head 63 is engaged by a fork on a bracket 68 adjustably mounted on a press-slide, shown at top deadcentre. When the air supply is turned on, air flows through valve 61 to close the guard, whereupon the press starts and the bracket 68 moves the head 63 to allow the valve 61 to close. When the press slide and the bracket 68 return to their uppermost positions, the head 63 is left behind but is slowly raised by the air pressure acting on piston 64, the rate of return being controlled by the restrictor 66, which thus determines the time interval before the head 63 reopens the valve 61 to start another cycle. Instead of being actuated by the bracket 68, the head 63 may be moved by mechanism actuated by the press crankshaft.

column12: Device for controlling the movement of a door
column13: The device, particularly for controlling the closing movement of a door (11, Fig. 6), comprises a linkage mechanism (45, 46, 47, 51) connected between the frame (10) and a door closer device (15) mounted on a backplate (13). Backplate-mounted means to retain the door open has a spring-biased arm (34, Fig. 2) movable downwards against spring (42) bias until a linkage part (51) on a catchplate (47) passes over, whereupon the arm rises so that a surface (38, Figs. 2 and 6) of the arm holds the linkage and door open. In manually shutting the door, the arm (34) is thrust down by the linkage part (51) so that the closer operates. To automatically shut the door, where fire is detected, an electromagnet is released to allow an arm (19) to pivot under spring bias and thus allow the spring-biased arm (34) to move axially and release the door. If the catch plate (47, Fig. 6) is free of the main arm (45) the door is free-swinging once it is moved to an open position. Accordingly simple fixing means (49, 50) are used so that conversion from a free-swinging door to a held open door or vice versa can easily be carried out. In the event of a fire however, the door is automatically closed by the released catchplate, regardless of whether it is in a free-swinging or held open state. <IMAGE>

column13: 920,508. Feeding webs. R. D. H. THOMPSON & CO. Ltd. Nov. 30, 1960 [Dec. 8, 1959], No. 41769/59. Class 100 (1). [Also in Groups XI and XV] In a bookbinding machine (see Group XV) for binding books, pamphlets, and the like by separate rings of flexible material passing through registering holes in the pages of the book, tapes 18 of polyvinyl chloride or polyethylene are fed upwardly from reels 17 corresponding in number to the number of holes in the book edge to a position beneath the book for forming said rings. The tapes pass over guide blocks 19 provided with non-return pawls 23 between the side walls 25 of gripper members which reciprocate along grooves in the plate 24 to feed the tapes forwardly, and are engaged at their upper ends by brake rods 32 mounted on a shaft 33 and having spring-loaded buttons 34 at their lower ends. The grippers comprise channel-shaped members having L-shaped side walls 25 mounted on a reciprocable shaft 26, a spring-loaded finger 30 being mounted between the side walls of each gripper on the shaft 26, to press against the tape passing therebeneath. The tapes are unwound from the reels by a swinging bar 37 and the brake rods lifted to disengage the tapes prior to feeding. The free ends of the tapes which are fed forwardly beneath the book are cut off by a reciprocating knife 42 and the ends of the tapes flattened against the plate 24 to facilitate further feeding by air blown through pipes 39b.

column12: Improvements in or relating to hydraulic dynamometers
column13: 856,573. Absorption dynamometers. HEENAN & FROUDE Ltd. May 2, 1958 [May 9, 1957], No. 14833/57. Class 106 (2). [Also in Groups XXIX and XXXIV] An hydraulic absorption dynamometer 1 is provided with a back-pressure valve 2 and means 13 responsive to the dynamometer speed for controlling the actuation of the valve 2 so that up to a selected predetermined speed the valve causes variable back pressure such that the power absorbed by the dynamometer varies with the cube of the speed and, upon the speed of the dynamometer exceeding that predetermined speed, the back pressure builds up rapidly so as to maintain the speed of the dynamometer substantially constant. The back pressure valve is shown in Fig. 2 and consists of a double mushroom valve a acting to open or close the water outlet 34 from the dynamometer casing 1. The valve a is mounted on a spindle b carrying a piston d, high-pressure oil from a pump 7, driven at a speed proportional to the speed of the dynamometer, being supplied to the left side of the piston through an inlet pipe 18, and low-pressure oil being supplied to the right side of the piston through an inlet 28. A spring n loads the spindle to the left to hold the valve a off its seatings under low load conditions. The speed-responsive means 13 is shown in Fig. 5 and consists of a piston c 6 loaded to the left by two adjustable tension springs h 6 . High-pressure oil from a pump 6 similar to the pump 7 is supplied to the left of the piston c 6 through an inlet 12, and the low-pressure oil being supplied to the backpressure valve 2 passes to the right of the piston c 6 between pipes 27 and 28, this path being cut-off if the piston c 6 moves to the right. Needle valves 15, 20 (Fig. 1), set by electric motors 21, 22, control the pressure of the oil in pipes 14, 19, upstream of these valves. The operation is as follows: If the speed is below the predetermined value, the pump 7 delivers oil through a filter 17 to the back-pressure valve 2 and by pressing its piston d to the right restricts the outflow of water through the outlet 34. For any one setting of the valve 20, the pressure set up behind the piston d will ensure that the back pressure against the water flowing through the outlet 34 will vary as the square of the speed, and hence the power absorbed will vary as the cube of the speed. Adjustment of the valve 20 regulates the factor of proportionality. Under these conditions, oil is supplied by the pump 6 through the valve 13 and the valve 15, which latter is partly closed, to the oil storage tank 3. When the speed of the dynamometer reaches the predetermined speed, the pressure to the left of the piston c 6 of the valve 13 rises sufficiently to move the piston over to the right, thus stopping the flow of oil through the pipes 27, 28 and this, overriding the action of the valve 20, causes an increase in pressure in the pipe 19. This in turn causes a sudden rise in the pressure applied to the piston d and hence a steep rise in the power absorbed. The speed at which this occurs is controlled by the adjustment of the springs h 6 and of the valve 15. If the tension in the springs h 6 is low, the valve 15 need only be closed slightly and the rate of movement of the piston c 6 is relatively low. If the tension in the springs h 6 is high, the valve 15 is closed further and the rate of movement of the piston c 6 is higher, thus ensuring that the speed stays more nearly constant as the power absorbed rises. In addition, a valve 23 controlling the rate of influx of water to the dynamometer is opened further by the rise of oil pressure in a pipe 26 caused by the closing of pipe 27. The Provisional Specification describes two further embodiments, in each of which the change from the cube law to constant speed absorption law is made manually, the apparatus operating to give substantially no power absorption up to a predetermined speed and then to operate on either of the above laws. Specifications 473,270 and 736,975 are referred to.

column13: A distillation probe comprises a pipe having a central axis. Moreover, the distillation probe comprises a baffle assembly disposed in the pipe. The baffle assembly comprises a plurality of axially spaced baffles vertically stacked with each other to be positioned inside the pipe. Each baffle has a central axis and an outer surface in a radial direction. Each baffle comprises a first recess unit disposed along the outer surface in the radial direction of the baffle, and additionally, extended in an axial direction through the baffle. In addition, each baffle comprises a plurality of cooling pipes mounted in the pipe and positioned to be adjacent to the pipe in the radial direction. The cooling pipes are configured to cool the pipe and the baffle.

column13: 5056. Evans, A. C., and Richards, D. L. Feb. 29. Laying dust.-In apparatus for damping dust in trains or journeys of laden trams in coal and other mines, of the kind in which the water spray is turned on and off by the moving vehicles, strikers k secured to the leading and the rearmost or other predetermined trams are arranged to contact with the upraised arm of a series of arms h<1>, h<2>, h<3>, &c., and so open or close the valve c through which water is admitted to the spraying-pipe l. An adjustable sleeve e is interposed between the valve spindle d and the wheel of arms h<1>, h<2>, h<3>, &c

15,093. Evans, G. A., and Meredith, J. E. July 7. Mules.-The object is to attach broken ends automatically to the spindles when the carriage approaches the roller beam. The loose ends hanging from the rollers fall into the notches of a plate I beneath, which, as the carriage completes its inward run, is moved horizontally close to the spindles, and is caused to follow them for a few inches on their outward run. The plate is carried by a frame G, which slides on rollers J and is connected to a weighted shaft E, so that, when the shaft is free, the plate I follows the spindles. The parts are shown in the position when the carriage has just completed its inward run. A bracket K on the carriage has passed the pivoted catch U on the lever M secured to the cam disc N on the shaft E without operating it, and the cam disc N, which, during the greater part of the outward and inward run, was blocked by the catch in the position shown by the catch 0, has been released by the pivoted stop P on the carriage. By the action of the weight T, the plate I is now pressed against the spindles and caused to follow them for a short distance on their outward run, until the bracket K engages with the catch U and moves the parts again into the position shown, in which they are blocked by the catch 0 until the carriage completes another inward run. A modification is shown in Fig. 1 (Sheet 2), in which the plate I is held in its most backward position by a weight Z, which is heavier than the weight T, is carried on the end of the lever Z', and is raised as the carriage completes its inward run by reason of the carriage moving an inclined slide beneath a roller Y on the lever.

A linearly adjustable de-vice comprising a main body including at least two body sections each having a lon-gitudinal axis, and a linear actuator. The sections are operatively connected togeth-er for linear movement relative to one an-other in the axial direction. The linear ac-tuator is operatively mounted to the main body for causing the relative axial move-ment between the body section. The linear actuator includes a drive and a power transmission mechanism operatively con-nected to the drive. The transmission mechanism includes an elongated thread-ed member operatively connected to one of the body sections and a cooperating threaded member operatively connected to another of the body sections such that relative rotation between the elongated threaded member and the cooperating threaded member causes relative move-ment of the body sections.

A supply of water is continuously monitored to ensure purity by dividing the supply into a number of parallel streams and flowing each through a fish tank (14) containing a fish (or other aquatic animal), the health of each fish being monitored by electrodes in each respective tank. The fish tanks are located together in a main tank (12) and the water supply is drawn from a header tank (16) via pipework (24), the tank (16) being fed from supply (18). The apparatus includes an electronic system to monitor the activity of the fish.

column12: Device for controlling the movement of a door
column13: The device, which is for controlling the movement of a door (11), particularly the closing movement, comprises a linkage mechanism (45-47) connected between the frame (10) and a door closer (15a) mounted on a backplate (13), and retaining means (38) on the backplate for normally preventing return movement of part (47) of the linkage mechanism once the door has been opened, the part (47) being a catch plate integral with a spindle (16) of the door closer which is thus biassed to rotate in the door closing direction. If the catch plate (47) and a main arm (45) of the linkage mechanism are connected together, by bolt (49), the door is held open once it is moved to an open position. If the catch plate (47) is free of the main arm (45) the door is free-swinging once in the open position, while the catch plate (47) is retained by means (38). In the free-swinging arrangement, the bolt is secured in plate slot 48 to be abutted by link (45). The re-positioning of the bolt is thus used to convert from a free-swinging door to a held-open door. In the event of a fire means (38) automatically releases plate (47) to be rotated by the closer 15 to close the door regardless of whether it is in a free-swinging or held-open state. Manual closure is also possible with a door in the held open state by overcoming the hold-open force. <IMAGE>

Improvements in or relating to the manufacture of titanium compounds
column13: In the manufacture of titanium dioxide pigments from mineral rutile, the latter is admixed with an oxide or carbonate of an alkali or alkaline earth metal or of magnesium and heated, in the absence of carbon, at 800-1100 DEG C to form a mixed titanate containing a high proportion of TiO2, say 80 per cent by weight. A suitable reaction mixture consists of 50-80 per cent mineral rutile, 10-40 per cent soda ash and 5-40 per cent chalk. On digestion with, say, 94 per cent sulphuric acid, the product yields a dry, porous mass readily soluble in water or dilute sulphuric acid. Specification 408,215 is referred to.

column12: Improvements in or relating to Oasts, Drying Kilns and the like.
column13: 20,893. White, W. L., and Evans, A. W. Sept. 16. Chambers, ovens, and like large rooms.-In an oast or kiln for drying hops &c., a modification of the apparatus described in Specification 21,039/12 is provided for lifting and shaking the hops &c. The apparatus, as shown, comprises triangular or other segments a furnished with series of cross wires or ropes on which the hops rest on the floor. Projections on their outer ends, furnished in some cases with rollers, engage guides e, while their inner ends rest on the lower of two connected pieces h, j sliding on a central rod. The segments are raised by cords k connected to the upper sliding piece j, and by the lower sliding piece h which supports their inner angles, the two members j, h being raised together by a cable m. The cords k pass over pulleys q slidably mounted on horizontal pins p, and means are provided for taking up slack. When the segments reach a certain height, their outer edges are held by stops f, so that they are pulled up against the walls. At their highest horizontal positions, or in some other determined positions, they are shaken, so that the hops fall and are redistributed on the floor, by a roller s pulled to and fro against the cable m by a lever, or by other means. The segment next the door may be cut away. Where a central air flue is provided, connected rings may encircle it in place of the sliding members h, j.

column12: Improvements in Tyres and in Rims for use therewith.

Tyre attachments to rims.-In tyres in which a solid rubber tread is supported on a pneumatic cushion inside a channel rim, the base b is made inextensible by canvas insertions and projects so far laterally that the wings are submitted to flexure without a tendency to pull on the beadings c or equivalent attaching-means. The beadings are formed with flaps f to protect the cushion. The rim flanges l are brought round over the beadings, and turned away from the sides of the tread at a short distance therefrom.

A linearly adjustable device comprising a main body including at least two body sections each having a longitudinal axis, and a linear actuator. The sections are operatively connected together for linear movement relative to one another in the axial direction. The linear actuator is operatively mounted to the main body for causing the relative axial movement between the body section. The linear actuator includes a drive and a power transmission mechanism operatively connected to the drive. The transmission mechanism includes an elongated threaded member operatively connected to one of the body sections and a cooperating threaded member operatively connected to another of the body sections such that relative rotation between the elongated threaded member and the cooperating threaded member causes relative movement of the body sections.

column12: Patio door security bar with lock
column13: A patio door or sliding window security bar which is of the type that is normally stored parallel to a frame member of the opening and movable to a horizontal position braced against the sliding panel frame or jamb so that the sliding panel cannot be moved to give access through the opening. A bolt is fully contained within the hollow bar end and capable of being reciprocated through the medium of a barrel or cylinder that is installed into the lateral wall of the bar to enable the bolt to be moved into a socket formed in the sliding panel frame to lock the bar against being swung upward or downward. A locking arrangement including a keyway enables the bar to be locked in horizontal position by means of a removable key to prevent unauthorized opening of the patio door even from the interior of the building having the opening.

column12: Improvements in or relating to the preparation of metallic halides
column13: A mixture of ilmenite and carbon is fluidized at 750-1000 DEG C preferably 850-1000 DEG C. in an insulated shaft furnace, sufficient chlorine being passed through a perforated base therein to chlorinate the metallic constituents at a rate proportional to their relative proportions in the ore and produce titanium tetrachloride and ferric chloride. The fluidized bed and/or the gaseous products of the chlorination may be cooled by a suitable liquid or solid cooling agent or a suspension of the latter in the former, specifically mentioned agents being ferric chloride and titanium tetrachloride. In the example, titanium tetrachloride was used to control the bed temperature at 970 DEG C. or below; ferric chloride was admitted to a first condenser to cool the gases to 300 DEG C.; an atomized spray of titanium tetrachloride cooled residual gases to 130 DEG C. and precipitated ferric chloride; and a series of tube condensers cooled the remaining gases to below -10 DEG C. to remove titanium tetrachloride; chlorine comprised less than 1 per cent of the original gaseous mixture. Suitable ores are low magnesium and calcium ilmenite sands containing, e.g. 60 per cent Ti O2, 25 per cent Fe and 1.2 per cent by weight alkali and alkaline earth oxides and having particle sizes from 20-1000m preferably 100-300m . About 10-30 per cent of charcoal or coke is added, having a particle size of 20-2000m preferably 50-600m . The process is preferably initiated with a bed of rutile and carbon in a furnace preheated by means of hot gases led or consumed therein, by the use of oxygen to react with said carbon, or preferably by playing a flame on to the mass fluidized by air. When the temperature reaches 8-900 DEG C., chlorine is admitted to continue the fluidization, and ilmenite carbon are fed in from the top in suitable proportions, there being generally used an amount of chlorine varying by 10 per cent, preferably 5 per cent on either side of the stoichiometric proportion. In the example, a furnace was used having a perforated base as described in Specification 724,193, in which the perforations are fitted with controlling orifices on the underside and gas-permeable discs are fitted to prevent the return of dust etc.
column15: EVANS ARTHUR WALLACE;;BENNETT ARTHUR NEVILLE COPNALL;;GROVES JAMES DENNIS

column12: Improvements in or relating to the manufacture of titanium dioxide pigments from mineral rutile ores
column13: In the production of titanium dioxide pigments, a mixture of mineral rutile and alkali metal compound is roasted above 750 DEG C. but without fusion to form alkali metal titanate which, preferably after grinding, is lixiviated with water to remove impurities, e.g. chromium, vanadium, and, preferably after further grinding, boiled with 10-32 per cent. by weight hydrochloric, or 5-32 per cent. sulphuric acid to leach only the alkali metal content, and the resulting titanium dioxide is then calcined at 500 DEG -1000 DEG C. suitably after treatment with neutralizing agents, or other agents such as zinc, magnesium, lithium, potassium, sodium, aluminium, antimony. The TiO2: alkali metal oxide ratio is preferably 1-4 : 1. The leaching acid may contain trivalent titanium, and the leaching time may be 2-20 hours. Alkali metal, particularly sodium and potassium, compounds to be mixed with the rutile are the carbonate, oxide, hydroxide, sulphide, or sulphate to which carbon may be added. Specifications 408,215 and 462,998 are referred to.
column15: EVANS ARTHUR WALLACE;;BENNETT ARTHUR NEVILLE COPNALL;;RUSSELL PATRICK JOSEPH

column12: Improvements in or relating to the preparation of titanium tetrachloride
column13: In the chlorination of a titaniferous material in the presence of carbon in a fluidized bed of the kind described in Specification 762,583, a titaniferous slag is employed which contains not more than 5% Al2O3, 0,5% Ca, 7,0% MgO and 3,0% SiO2 respectively. Carbon in the form of coke may constitute 10-30% of the mixture which preferably is from 124 to 353 microns in size. The chlorination temperature may be from 1000 DEG to 1200 DEG C. and the fluidizing gas velocity is preferably 7-20 times the minimum. A quantity of slag and carbon corresponding to 11 times the weight of the initial bed may be chlorinated in continuous operation before sticking or impurity accumulation necessitate purging.

column13: 25,574. Wichmann, G. C. H., and Evans, A. B. Nov. 23. Lithographic printing.-In lithographic machiues, particularly of the rotary or flat bed types, the sheet is stroked by a brush to prevent creases, the pressure, time of operation, and also if desirable the width of the brush being adjustable. Each of several sections f of the brush is held by two arms e, adjustably mounted on a shaft d and held by a set-screw e', the shaft having a flat d<1> so that the hook-shaped ends of the arms e can be easily removed from the shaft, which is supported by brackets c on the main brackets b supporting the bearings of the impression cylinder. The brush is caused to bear on the paper by the action of a spring o, with a force adjustable by a screw r, the point of which bears against the framing b, the brush being lifted away from the cylinder, where there is no paper, by a cam n fixed on the shaft; this cam has an adjustable part n' clamped to it by a nut q, the cam moving a roller m on a lever h, one end of which is slotted and guided by a bolt i in the cylinder shaft end, and the other end of which actuates a crank g on the end of the shaft d.

column12: Four Wheel Drive, Zero Turn Radius Mower
column13: A mower apparatus and method for making the same is provided. A mower apparatus may include a multi-wheel drive mower system having at least one mower blade and at least one front wheel positioned proximate the front of the mower system and at least one rear wheel positioned proximate the rear of the mower system. The mower apparatus may also include a zero turn assembly haying at least one caster wheel. The zero turn assembly may be rotatably attached to the multi-wheel drive mower system to provide the mower apparatus with the capability of operating in either a multi-wheel drive mode having at least the at least one front wheel and the at least one rear wheel engaging the ground or a zero turn radius mode having only the at least one caster wheel and the at least one rear wheel engaging the ground.

column12: Fluidised bed process for the production of titanium dioxide
column13: Titanium dioxide is recovered from above a hot fluidized bed in which, in the presence of a source of K, Rb or Cs, an oxygenating gas reacts with titanium tetrahalide other than TiF4. The K, Rb or Cs source may be added batchwise to the bed, giving a concentration by weight (estimated as oxide) with respect to the weight of the bed of 0.1-5%; or continuously, with concentration with respect to TiO2 produced of 2%; if 0.1-1% of a source of Na, Li or Group IIa or IIb elements be added to the bed, only 0.01-0.05% K, Rb or Cs is required. The sources of the elements may be salts, hydroxides or the elemental metals, e.g. as vapour. The source may be introduced, e.g. with a reactant, as a solid or liquid or a solution; the bed particles may be slurried with source solution and dried before use; or the source may itself form all or part of the bed particles, e.g. as potassium aluminium silicate. The titanium tetrahalide, e.g. TiCl4, may be introduced as a vapour; the oxygenating gas may be O2 with or without inert gas, e.g. as air; other gases, e.g. N2, may also be introduced. The bed temperature is 800 DEG -1200 DEG C. Additional heat may or may not be supplied, e.g. electrical heating, preheating one or more input gases, or burning a fuel, e.g. CO, in the bed with additional oxygenating gas. Bed particles, e.g. SiO2, ZrSiO4, Al2,O3 or TiO2, have size 50-2,000 m . Minor proportions of rutilizing agents, e.g. aluminium halide, zirconium tetrahalide, water vapour, or other TiO2 crystal-modifying agents, e.g. halides of Si, Sb and P, may be added. The TiO2 may be recovered from the effluent gas by use of a cyclone to remove larger particles and filtration to recover pigmentary TiO2. The gaseous halogen product may be separated by liquefaction and used to produce more titanium tetrahalide. In examples the pigmentary TiO2 recovered had rutile content of about 98%; after wet milling the bed material up to about 13% of the trahalide admitted was retained thereon as TiO2; in a contrasting run in which the source was omitted, 40% tetrahalide was retained. Specifications 761,770 and 986,660 are referred to.

The first engaging member 5 may also be formed with a tyre lever (figure 5). In other embodiments (figures 6a-c) the actuating member may be extendable in length, and in another embodiment (figure 7) the actuating member is removable.

column13: Silicon dioxide is prepared by the oxidation of silicon tetrachloride vapour in a fluidized bed of inert solid particles. In the preferred process, the particles, which may be of silica, alumina, zircon, or nitrile, have sizes from 40m to 1000m , and the bed is maintained at a temperature of 500 DEG to 1200 DEG C. After passing through the bed, the products, silicon dioxide and chlorine, are cooled and separated, the chlorine being used to prepare further silicon tetrachloride. The silicon dioxide may either be washed with water, or treated with steam above 250 DEG C.

column13: Temperature control at a weld (52) between a tube (51) and tube plate (53) having heat input from an inductive heating probe (50) to effect annealing of the weld is performed with the aid of a signal generating receptor coil (54) coupled with the probe (50). The signal from the coil (54) experiences a characteristic change when the temperature of the weld reaches the required annealing temperature and this signal is used to control the heat input to the weld. The receptor coil can be inside the tube (51), outside the tube (51), embracing a number of similar tubes (51) or may be inside an adjacent tube (51). At the anneal, the materials of the tube and weld reach their Curie point which brings about a permeability change. The invention also has application to annealing a braze between a ferritic repair tube and a ferritic tube in a tube plate as can arise during the repair of shell and tube heat exchangers used in nuclear systems.

column12: Improvements in Machines for Printing on Tin Plate or the like.
column13: 24,487. Wichmann, G. C. H., and Evans, A. B. Nov. 11. Lithographic and like printing; feeding sheets.- A machine for printing on tin plates and the like has a roller c, Fig. 1, carrying an aluminium or similar printing-surface, suitably damped and inked in the usual manner, and transferring the design to a cylinder b having a rubber or like surface, from which the design is pressed on to the tin plate, carried round between the gripper and impression cylinder a and the printing cylinder b. The shaft b<1> of the cylinder b runs in eccentric bearings q, and the cylinder may be moved out of contact with the cylinders c, a, when desired, during the printing operation by pressing the pedal v. This action depresses the tumbler u, and allows the link s, reciprocated by the cam t<1>, roller t, and lever s<1> to pull over the lever r<1> during the printing operation, and thereby, through the lever r, an adjustable link, and the lever q<1>, partly turns the eccentric bushes q on each side of the machine and moves the cylinder b oat of action. When the pedal v rises through the action of a spring, the hook at the end of the link s no longer engages the pin r', and the cylinder b remains in working position. The sheets of tin are fed by hand, one by one, from a table f to a vertical steel face-plate g, Figs. 1 and 2, supported on a feed-board g<1> mounted on brackets g<2>. The lower edge passes between springs i adjustably mounted on a guidebar i<1> and smoothers k on the shaft k<1>, and finally rests on the tips of the arms h mounted on a shaft h<1>. The sheet is then gripped by the grippers e, and at the same time a cam m on the cylinder a, lowers the arms h through a roller n on a lever n<1> engaging a roller o on a lever o<1> on the shaft h<1>, and also moves backwards the smoothers k through the extra links and levers h<2>, k<2>. The sheet being vertical, its own weight helps to overcome its inertia, and it passes down between the guides l and the cylinder a, is printed on by the cylinder b, and pulled past the guides l<1>, Fig. 1, the hindmost edge springing outwards immediately it has passed the guides l<1>. At the same time the grippers e are turned backwards to release the front edge of the sheet, which falls printed side uppermost on the table l'. The grippers are opened by a pin p<1>, Fig. 2, mounted on an arm adjustable in position, engaging with a slot in a piece d<1> on the end of the gripper shaft, the grippers being turned backwards through nearly 180‹ in the slot a<1>, and are closed on the sheet by a similar pin p fixed to the framework, entering and leaving the other end of the slot in the piece d<1>, thereby turning the grippers forward.

column12: Production of titanium dioxide by vapour phase oxidation
column13: TiO2 is produced by reacting a titanium tetrahalide (not fluoride), an aluminium halide (not fluoride), and an oxygenating gas in a fluidized bed of particles containing Si and O in chemical combination, the aluminium and titanium halides being introduced separately. Of the total bed particles having diameter 40-1000m , preferably at least 25% contain Si-O bonds, e.g. zircon sand ZrO2SiO2, sillimanite Al2O3SiO2, or pure SiO2. A bed temperature of 900-1200 DEG C. is maintained. Ti halide, preferably TiCl4, is introduced at 150-800 DEG C., and moisture may also be separately introduced. Al halide, preferably AlCl3 may be fed at 100-600 DEG C., in the oxygenating gas, e.g. O2, air, and is in a quantity such that 0.1-10% preferably 2-4% by weight of Al2O3 relative to TiO2 is produced. 60-80% of the TiO2 produced is contained in the effluent gas and can be recovered by known methods, while the remaining TiO2 is accreted on the bed particles which are continuously or intermittently removed and subjected to abrasion by wet or dry milling processes. A wet process, using fine sand ball mills, of particle size 250-1000m , and water is preferred, the sand being subsequently separated from the pigment by sieving or preferential settling.

column12: Probe assembly for testing integrated circuit devices
column13: A probe assembly adapted to test an integrated circuit (IC) device whose contact pads are deployed in a predetermined pattern in a common plane. The assembly includes a film membrane having a planar dielectric contactor zone and an array of suspension wings radiating from this zone. The wings are clamped at their ends by a mounting ring surrounding a port in a printed circuit board which exposes the contactor zone suspended below the board to the IC device to be tested, the ring being secured to the board. Deployed in a matching pattern on the exposed face of the contactor zone and cantilevered therefrom to assume an angle with respect thereto are spring contact fingers that are extensions of traces running along the wings of the membrane to leads on the printed circuit board. These leads extend to respective test terminals on the board which are connectable to electronic instrumentation for conducting tests on the IC device. When the IC device is raised to bring its contact pads into engagement with the spring fingers, this action causes the fingers to flex inwardly, and in doing so to scrub the contact pads and thereby ensure effective electrical contact therewith.

column13: Temperature control at a weld (52) between a tube (51) and tube plate (53) having heat input from an inductive heating probe (50) to effect annealing of the weld is performed with the aid of a signal generating receptor coil (54) coupled with the probe (50). The signal from the coil (54) experiences a characteristic change when the temperature of the weld reaches the required annealing temperature and this signal is used to control the heat input to the weld. The receptor coil can be inside the tube (51), outside the tube (51), embracing a number of similar tubes (51) or may be inside an adjacent tube (51). At the anneal, the materials of the tube and weld reach their Curie point which brings about a permeability change. The invention also has application to annealing a braze between a ferritic repair tube and a ferritic tube in a tube plate as can arise during the repair of shell and tube heat exchangers used in nuclear systems.

column13: <PICT:0919018/III/1> Silicon dioxide is produced by reacting silicon tetrachloride vapour with oxygen in the presence of a fluidized bed of inert solid materials, the silicon dioxide being produced within the bed and being discharged in entrainment in the outgoing gases. The reactants are separately introduced through inlet ducts in a perforated base of the fluidized bed, the perforations being provided with inserts forming constrictions such that the pressure drop thereacross is at least one half of the pressure drop from the bottom to top of the fluidized bed. The bed is of sufficient size to act as a heat reservoir to avoid the necessity of supplying extra heat. It is desirable however to preheat the oxygen to avoid condensation of the silicon tetrachloride vapour. The velocity of the fluidizing gas is preferably between 2 and 50 times the minimum required for fluidization and the pressure drop across the constrictions will generally be more than 2 p.s.i. Excess reaction heat may be withdrawn by conventional coolers or by the employment of gaseous coolants such as chlorine, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, or cooled recycled tail gases or by liquid chlorine injected into or sprayed upon the bed; additional cooling may be effected by progressively introducing relatively cool sand or other inert material to the bed whilst discharging hot material thereby maintaining the temperature from 500 DEG -1300 DEG C. and more particularly at about 1000 DEG C. The silica reaction product, separated from the gases by means of cyclones may be freed from adsorbed or combined chlorine by heating to 300 DEG -600 DEG C. by passing air countercurrent to the silica reaction product in a rotary tube or by fluidizing the hot reaction product with cold gas. If oxygen is employed for this purpose it may then be fed as a pre-heated reactant to the main oxidation process. The after-treatment gas may also contain ammonia or water vapour to assist in the removal or neutralization of the adsorbed chlorine in the silicon dioxide product. The silicon chloride and oxygen reactants are generally employed in stoichiometric amounts but the oxygen tetrachloride ratio may vary from 1:1 to 5:1 on a molar basis. Moisture is preferably, but not necessarily, avoided. The apparatus employed may be that described and claimed in Specification 919,020. Thus, as shown in Fig. 1, a heat insulated reaction chamber is provided with a perforated base having inlets 112 connected to a manifold 26 for the supply of silicon tetrachloride and inlets 212 and 312 for oxygen connected to manifold 25. Each inlet is provided with a constriction plate 43 which produces the requisite pressure drop. Reaction products are withdrawn through line 126 and cool sand is fed from a fluidized bed 73 through pipe 70 to the main reaction bed whilst excess sand is withdrawn through a line 77 to a bed fluidized with air fed through line 85 and leaving through a pipe 84. The sand is finally withdrawn through line 83. An alternative base plate construction is shown in Fig. 5, where separate wind boxes 404 and 405 are fed with oxygen and the tetrachloride respectively through lines 406 and 407. The fluidized bed is supported on a perforated refractory base plate 11 having ceramic inserts 400 provided with downwardly directed outlets 410. The lower end of the ceramic inserts are provided with screw plugs 402 having pressure reducing orifices 403. Silica reaction product entrained in the gases leaving through line 126 (Fig. 1) are first separated in a cyclone separator from the chlorine-containing reacted gases, and then treated to remove undesired acidity for example by feeding to a fluidized bed where they are treated with air or oxygen, containing ammonia with or without water vapour, whereby the pH of the product is above 3,5. According to a typical example, silica sand of average diameter 250 microns constituted the main reaction bed to which oxygen was fed together with silicon tetrachloride through a steam jacketed vaporizing tube. The tetrachloride oxygen molar ratio was 1-1,5. The reaction temperature was maintained at 1000 DEG -1050 DEG C. by continuous slow replacement of the silica which was heated to 400 DEG C. in the fluidized bed 71 before passage to the main reactor. The silica product had an average particle size of 0,004 microns and a bulk density of 4 1/2 pounds per cubic foot. The surface area was 260 square metres per gram and its pH after heat treatment was 4,1. Specification 796,735 also is referred to.

By this machine two sheets can be treated at every revolution of the transfer cylinder, or, by off-setting on to the impression cylinder, one sheet may be perfected in exact register. This latter method is useful for printing transparencies.

Rotary machines; lithographic and like printing. -A rotary machine for printing in one or more colours and perfecting sheets of paper, metal, &c. comprises a forme cylinder a having two or more lithographic or other printing-surfaces clamped thereon, and inked in one or more colours by inking-devices e, p, q. The formes print on to rubber blankets on the transfer cylinder b, and the impressions are then either transferred direct to the sheet which passes from the feed-table h between the cylinders b, c, or one of them is first transferred on to the cylinder c, so that it is printed on the reverse side of the sheet. By arranging the sheet to travel a suitable number of times round with the cylinder c before delivery, and by varying the number of plates on the cylinder a, a sheet may be printed on either side, perfected, printed in several colours, or perfected and printed in several colours. The diameter of the cylinders a, b is an exact multiple of the diameter of the cylinder c.

column13: A test probe assembly for testing an integrated circuit (IC) device having contact pads deployed in a predetermined pattern in a common plane. The assembly includes a contactor formed by a flexible film of dielectric material having a rectangular planar central zone from whose corners extend radial slots to define suspension quadrants. The quadrants are marginally supported on corresponding branches of a mounting frame whereby the central zone sags below the frame which surrounds a central port in a printed circuit board, the port exposing the central zone to the IC device to be tested.

column13: This invention relates to toothpaste containing an alumina hydrate abrasive and a source of fluoride. According to the invention, there is provided a toothpaste containing a source of fluoride ions and unmilled, precipitated alumina trihydrate as an abrasive, wherein the alumina trihydrate particles have a median particle size of at least 3 micrometres. The median particle size of the alumina trihydrate is preferably below 30 micrometres, more preferably from 5 to 20 micrometres, and most preferably 8 to 12 micrometres. It has been found that the use of an unmilled alumina trihydrate, obtained by precipitation, substantially reduces the loss of available fluoride on storage whereas the use of a milled alumina trihydrate causes significant loss of available fluoride.

column12: Vapour phase oxidation of titanium tetrachloride
column13: In the production of titanium dioxide by passing a titanium halide together with oxygen or air upwardly through a bed of inert solids to fluidise them, the velocity of the gas and vapour stream is maintained at such a value that the bulk of the reaction is effected above the surface of the bed, whereby a zone of higher temperature is established above the bed. The bed may be made up of particles of silica, alumina, zircon or rutile and the reaction chamber preferably has a perforated base below which air or oxygen is fed. Additional oxygen may be fed in admixture with the titanium tetrahalide feed, which may pass through a part of the perforated base or be fed from a point above the base. Alternatively titanium tetrahalide may be fed from the side or the top of the reaction chamber, and injected as gas or liquid into the bed just above the base through tube jets; part of the tetrahalide feed may be in liquid form from the top of the bed. Titanium tetrachloride is usually employed but the tetrabromide or tetraiodide may be used. The reaction is generally self-sustaining, but fuel gases such as carbon monoxide may be admixed with the tetrachloride reactant. The temperature in the bed is normally from 700 DEG -1200 DEG C. whilst the temperature above the bed is slightly higher. Molar ratios of tetrachloride to oxygen may be from 1-0,2 to 1-3. According to an example a vertical shaft reaction chamber containing zircon sand was fed with titanium tetrachloride vapour through four central inlets from a common manifold, and oxygen through eight inlets on both sides of the tetrachloride ports. The bed was preheated to 970 DEG C. and on reaction fell to 930 DEG C. whilst the temperature above the bed was about 990 DEG C. Specification 761,770 is referred to.

column13: Titanium dioxide of which more than 95% is in the rutile form is made by the reaction between an oxygenating gas and a titanium tetrahalide, in the presence of hot inert solid particles and of zirconium tetrahalide; the term "halide" does not include "fluoride." The particles, of diameter range 74-1800 m , may be of TiO2, and may contain 1% KCl, and a bed thereof may be fluidized or in the form of a heat-exchanging fountain circulating between two stages. An inert gas may be added to assist fluidization. The reaction temperature of 900-1200 DEG C. may be maintained autothermally; alternatively an external source of heat may additionally be used, e.g. by burning a fuel, e.g. oil, C, CO, or by electrical heating. The proportion of Zr tetrahalide is 0.5-7% by weight of Ti tetrahalide, calculated as the oxides or a proportion of Zr tetrahalide such that up to 25% of the weight of the final product is ZrO2. The halides are preferably the chlorides. The oxygenating gas may be oxygen with or without an inert gas, e.g. as air. Other substances may be added to the bed, e.g. 0.1-10% Al trihalide, 0.01-1% Si tetrahalide, 0.01-1% water, or a source of K, Rb or Cs. The halides of Ti and Zr may be preheated to form vapour and the vapours led into the reaction zone mixed or separately; if the Zr halide and oxygenating gas are introduced together, they should be preheated to below reaction temperature, e.g. up to 300 DEG C. In a fluidized bed, about 60-80% TiO2 formed will be entrained in the effluent gases, and is mainly rutile. The residual TiO2 mainly forms an aceretion on the bed particles; excess bed material is removed continuously or at intervals and may be ground, wet or dry, in mills with e.g. at least one surface of polyurethane rubber. The particulate matter and ground-off TiO2 particles may be classified by gas or liquid separation; the particles are returned to the reaction zone; the ground-off TiO2 may be used, e.g. in vitreous enamels. In examples, up to 72% of TiO2 produced was entrained, up to 99% was in rutile form, tinting strength was up to 1680 (Reynolds scale) and mean crystal size was down to 0.15 m . Specifications 761,770, 860,301, 900,050, 919,019, 968,660, 968,832 and 988,878 are referred to.

column12: Improvement in the vapour phase oxidation of titanium tetrahalide to produce rutile pigment
column13: Pigmentary TiO2 is prepared by the vapour phase oxidation of a titanium tetrahalide in a fluidized bed of inert particulate matter wherein a small amount of an aluminium halide (not a fluoride) is introduced into the bed separately from the titanium tetrahalide and a small amount of a silicon halide (not a fluoride) is introduced into the bed separately from the aluminium halide. Preferably the aluminium halide is introduced in admixture with all or part of the oxygen-containing gas required for the reaction; in the latter case it is preferred that the oxygen-containing gas introduced with the aluminium halide is at least five times the amount required to oxidize the aluminium halide. Any oxygen-containing gas not introduced with the aluminium halide is introduced either alone or with the titanium tetrahalide. In the illustrated embodiment the apparatus comprises a fused silica tube 1 containing a bed 5 surrounded by a furnace 8 and sealed at its base with a silica disc 2 through which pass inlets 3 and 4. Aluminium trichloride and oxygen are supplied to inlet 3, the oxygen <PICT:0986660/C1/1> being supplied from pipe 9 and the aluminium trichloride being provided by passing chlorine from pipe 11 through heated reactor tube 12 containing aluminium turnings. Titanium tetrachloride in admixture with silicon tetrachloride is introduced at inlet 4, the feed being introduced as a liquid to pipe 14 and vaporized in 15. Alternatively the silicon tetrachloride can be introduced by pipe 18 either alone or with a carrier gas such as chlorine. The bed 5, of dense TiO2 particles (-44 + 72 BSS), is initially fluidized with air until external heating by means of furnace 8 has raised it to 900 DEG -1200 DEG C. The process may be carried out in the presence of a small proportion of moisture e.g. less than 2% by weight of the titanium tetrahalide. During the process 60 to 80% of the TiO2 formed is entrained, mainly in rutile form, in the affluent gases and carried away from the reaction chamber. The remainder of the TiO2 forms loosely bound accretions on the particles constituting the bed thus causing the bed to increase in volume. The excess bed, or the whole bed, is removed and subjected to attrition, using wet or dry milling processes, to remove the loosely bound particles from the substrate and to separate them from one another, and the substrate material may then be returned to the bed. The amount of aluminium and silicon halides introduced is preferably such that the weights of each of the alumina and silica in the final TiO2 pigment will be 0.1 to 7% and the relative proportions of the two halides introduced is normally such as to produce a weight ratio of alumina to silica in the final pigment of 20:1 to 1:5. Specifications 900,050 and 919,019 are referred to.

column12: Electronic Banking Management For Betting Games
column13: Electronic banking management for betting games is described. In one implementation, a multiparticipant electronic gaming table has a banking engine that dynamically determines current participants and authenticates qualified participants as banker candidates. The banking engine tracks game flow in order to determine when to offer the banking role to other participants. In one implementation, the system has an accounts manager that tracks wagers during the game, updates participant account balances, tracks transactions of each participant holding the banking role, and balances the bank of each participant in the banking role.

column13: Sensing means for speed and direction of movement of a body (10) movable in an ambient fluid in a direction transverse to the longitudinal axis (11). Flow sensing means comprises a sound source and sound receivers (21) associated with respective bores (15) is provided to determine the phase shift caused by the fluid flow in each bore and hence determine the direction and speed of fluid flow. column13: Finely divided titanium dioxide is obtained by vaporizing solid material containing titanium dioxide by contacting it with a substantially inert gas heated to a temperature above the boiling point of titanium dioxide and condensing the vaporized material. The heated gas may be in the form of a plasma and may be e.g. argon, oxygen or free-oxygen containing gas such as air, nitrogen, helium, neon, krypton, carbon dioxide or oxides of nitrogen. a minor proportion of a gas which has a high thermal conductivity, e.g. hydrogen, may be included. The heating may be in the form of an arc between electrodes preferably arranged as a central electrode and an annular electrode both of which may be cooled by means of a circulating liquid coolant. The current may be direct or alternating. Induction heating may be employed by passing the gas through a space surrounded by a confining tube of e.g. silica and around which is wound electrically conducting material, e.g. copper tubing carrying an alternating current of, say, 200 kilocycles to 10 megacycles. A gaseous or liquid coolant, e.g. water, may be passed through the coil. The gas may be in helical or laminar flow or a mixture of both. The first and last turns of the coil may be in a direction opposite to that of the remainder. The particles of titaniferous material may be of 30-100 microns and may be added to the gas stream as described in Specification 1,093,442. The condensed material may be subjected to a magnetic or electric field. A rutilizing agent, e.g. an aluminium halide or zirconium tetrachloride may be added before vaporization and other <PICT:1093441/C1/1> modifying agents, e.g. compounds of silicon or boron such as the halides, or lower halides of titanium, water or alkali metal ions may be added before or after vaporization. An apparatus as shown comprises two silica tubes (1) and (2), around (1) are wound coils of copper tubing (3) connected to a radio-frequency generator. A silica tube (4) provides an annular space (5) through which gas may be passed. Silica tube 6 with orifice (7) is attached to a supply of particulate material and feed gas. The lower end of (2) is connected through a filter to a source of reduced pressure. Tube (2) is cooled with air through pipes 8.

column12: Heating Units for Heating Enclosures and Methods of Heating Enclosures
column13: A heating unit for heating an enclosure includes a base having a central axis, a first end, a second end axially opposite the first end, and a cavity extending axially from the first end. In addition, the heating unit includes a heater disposed in the cavity of the base. Further, the heating unit includes a heat sink mounted to the base. The heat sink includes a plurality of laterally spaced fins and a plurality of laterally spaced channels positioned between the plurality of fins. Still further, the heating unit includes a manifold coupled to the base. A surface of the manifold faces the base and the heat sink. The manifold includes a flow passage and a plurality of orifices in fluid communication with the flow passage. Each orifice has an outlet at the surface of the manifold that is aligned with one of the channels of the first heat sink.

column13: This invention relates to toothpaste containing an alumina hydrate abrasive and a source of fluoride. According to the invention, there is provided a toothpaste containing a source of fluoride ions and unmilled, precipitated alumina trihydrate as an abrasive, wherein the alumina trihydrate particles have a median particle size of at least 3 micrometres. The median particle size of the alumina trihydrate is preferably below 30 micrometres, more preferably from 5 to 20 micrometres, and most preferably 8 to 12 micrometres. It has been found that the use of an unmilled alumina trihydrate, obtained by precipitation, substantially reduces the loss of available fluoride on storage whereas the use of a milled alumina trihydrate causes significant loss of available fluoride.

column13: Simulated degraded sensor data may be generated for use in training a model. For instance, first sensor data collected by a sensor of a perception system of an autonomous vehicle may be received and converted into the simulated degraded sensor data for a particular degrading condition, such as a weather-related degrading condition. Then, the simulated degraded sensor data may be used to train a model for evaluating performance of the perception system to detect objects external to the autonomous vehicle under one or more conditions.

column13: ESTA INVENCION TRATA DE UNA PASTA DE DIENTES QUE CONTIENE UN ABRASIVO DE HIDRATO DE ALUMINIO Y SABORIZANTE. DE ACUERDO CON LA INVENCION, SE PROPORCIONA UNA PASTA DE DIENTES QUE CONTIENE UN SABORIZANTE Y NO MOLIDO, CON TRIHIDRATO DE ALUMINIO PRECIPITADO COMO ABRASIVO, EN DONDE LAS PARTICULAS DE TRIHIDRATO DE AL TIENEN UN TAMAÑO DE PARTICULA MEDIO DE AL MENOS 3 MICROMETROS. EL TAMAÑO DE PARTICULA MEDIO DEL TRIHIDRATO DE AL SE PREFIERE POR DEBAJO DE 30 MICROMETROS, MAS PREFERIBLEMENTE DE 5 A 20, Y MAS TODAVIA DE 8 A 12. SE HA ENCONTRADO QUE EL USO DE TRIHIDRATO DE AL NO MOLIDO, OBTENIDO POR PRECIPITACION, REDUCE LA CANTIDAD DE MATERIAL SABORIZANTE QUE SE REQUIERE PARA OBTENER UN SABOR FUERTE EN COMPARACION CON UN CONTENIDO EQUIVALENTE DE TRIHIDRATO DE AL MOLIDO CON UN TAMAÑO DE PARTICULA SIMILAR.

column13: 1,219,268. Current measurement. MULLARD Ltd. Jan. 24 1969 [Jan. 26, 1968; Nov. 19, 1968], Nos.4232/68 and 54879/68. Heading G1V. A current measuring system for use with large currents on a high voltage conductor incorporates a search unit incorporating a secondary winding on a magnetic core surrounding the conductor which provides an output which is used to energize the magnetizing coils of two or more Faraday effect devices. The actions of all the Faraday devices on a plane polarized light beam are combined to provide a beam whose polarization rotation represents the current to be measured. In one arrangement Fig. 1 the search unit incorporates a single winding 3 on a core 2 surrounding the conductor 1 and the output of this energizes two differently dimensioned magnetizing coils 6, 7 for two Faraday effect bodies 8, 9 through which a plan polarized infrared beam from a source S is passed. The plane polarized beam is additively rotated by each of the coils 6, 7. This system provides automatic range changing, the system being particularly sensitive to small currents because of the strong magnetic excitation per ampere turn due to coil 6. When the saturation level of the element associated with this is reached however it makes no further contribution to beam rotation and the system responds in a less sensitive manner to larger currents, further rotation being produced only by the coil 7. Alternatively two separate, differently sized coils may be arranged on the core 2, each supplying similarly sized coils 6, 7 Fig. 2 (not shown). The rotations may be subtractive, the currents in the windings 6, 7 rotating the beam in opposite directions so that there is no resultant rotation until one of the elements saturates, whereafter the other causes an output to be produced. In this way the system will respond only to currents to be measured in excess of a threshold. A similar technique may be used for temperature compensation. Faraday materials with different temperature co-efficients are used so chosen that when their effects on the plane polarized beam are subtractive temperature compensation is effected. Where all the elements are the same, and their effects are added, a system of improved sensitivity results. In a system for reducing interference due to near-by conductors or steady fields on a Faraday device, two such devices are arranged side by side and an optical mirror system is arranged to reflect a plan polarized beam transmitted through one of then back in the opposite direction through the other. The magnetizing coils are wound so as to rotate the beam additively as it passes each device. Interfering fields will however produce a subtractive, cancelling effect in the two coils, Fig. 6. All the arrangements previously described may be used in this system, by associating a further Faraday device with each of the two main devices. These further devices may have their windings in series with those of the main devices or may be energized from a separate winding on the core 2. Figs. 7 and 8 (not shown).

column12: HEATING UNITS FOR HEATING ENCLOSURES AND METHODS OF HEATING ENCLOSURES
column13: A heating unit for heating an enclosure includes a base having a central axis, a first end, a second end axially opposite the first end, and a cavity extending axially from the first end. In addition, the heating unit includes a heater disposed in the cavity of the base. Further, the heating unit includes a heat sink mounted to the base. The heat sink includes a plurality of laterally spaced fins and a plurality of laterally spaced channels positioned between the plurality of fins. Still further, the heating unit includes a manifold coupled to the base. A surface of the manifold faces the base and the heat sink. The manifold includes a flow passage and a plurality of orifices in fluid communication with the flow passage. Each orifice has an outlet at the surface of the manifold that is aligned with one of the channels of the first heat sink.

column12: Small, portable, self-contained, video teleconferencing system
column13: The present Invention relates to a portable, self-contained, briefcase-sized device capable of transmitting and receiving encrypted or unencrypted video teleconferencing communications over a variety of telecommunications mediums. The system contains a liquid crystal flat panel display, a flexible gooseneck video camera, built-in microphones and speakers, a pop-up bay to receive a military or civilian encryption unit, a variety of input and output connections, a modem-codec and ancillary electronics circuitry, a remote control device, interconnecting cabling, and operating software, all contained within a portable, metal reinforced, lockable, briefcase-type enclosure. The Invention can be connected to a telecommunications link such as a LAN, an Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) line provided by the local telephone company, or a Satellite Communications (SATCOM) system such as the International Maritime Satellite (INMARSAT) System. Through such communication connections the Invention can receive and transmit live video, videotape, or data, to distant end-stations equipped with the Invention or any standardized Video Teleconferencing (VTC) system.

column12: SYSTEMS, METHODS, AND DEVICES FOR EFFICIENTLY TRANSFERRING THERMAL ENERGY
column13: A thermal energy transfer unit for use in heating or cooling an object is disclosed. The thermal energy transfer unit includes opposing first and second pliable cover layers. A thermal energy spreading element is disposed between the first and second cover layers. The thermal energy spreading element comprises carbon thermally coupled to a thermal energy unit. column13: Silicon carbide of pigmentary or smaller size is prepared by reacting vaporized silicon oxide with a carbonaceous material (preferably a hydrocarbon) in a radio frequency induced plasma. The reaction zone 2 is surrounded by a coil 9 connected to a radio frequency source. Silicon oxide particles of diameter less than 210 microns, and suspended in an inert gas, are fed in through tube 1. The carbonaceous material in an inert carrier enters through 4. The plasma is induced at the end of tube 1 and may be stabilized by a reverse turn at either (or both) ends of the coil. The reaction temperature is less than 2700 DEG C. Deposition of Si or C on the porous walls 6 is prevented by a gas, which may be H2, CO or A which is transpired <PICT:1093443/C1/1> through the wall. The ratio of transpired gas to working gas is between 10:1 and 1:10. The gas stream emerging from the plasma is cooled in a water-cooled heat-exchanger 12 which may contain a cylindrical copper block 15 to aid heat exchange. The product is collected either by filter bag 17, or by electrostatic precipitation.

column13: Recombinant DNA constructs include 5' and 3' retroviral LTR sequences, a genome packaging sequence, a promoter sequence and a eukaryotic cDNA sequence under the promotional control of the promoter sequence. By making the retroviral sequences of the construct deficient in coat protein-encoding sequences, the construct is by itself incapable of packaging its genome as a retrovirion. The promoter sequence may be a viral LTR sequence. Alternatively the promoter sequence may be a nonviral promoter linked to the cDNA sequence, promoting the cDNA irrespective of cellular mechanisms which affect viral sequence expression. The retroviral genomes corresponding to the constructs are rescued as complete packaged virions by helper virus vectors which encode the coat proteins that are needed to package the genomes corresponding to the constructs. Helper virus vectors that are deficient in packaging sequences do not package their own genomes, and cells incorporating such a deficient helper virus vector and also a construct shed only retrovirions that are infectious a single time. Helper viral vectors which produce amphotropic proteins package recombinant retrovirions that are infective of cells of a variety of species. Cells infected with recombinant retrovirions are transplantable into an animal to comprise a portion of the somatic cells of the animal and express recombinant gene product therein. Recombinant retrovirionsaccording to the invention, if inoculated into the peripheral fluid of a host animal, will infect and genetically alter the somatic cells of the animal.

column13: Des constructions d'ADN recombinant comprennent des séquences rétrovirales 5' et 3' se répétant à long terme, une séquence d'enveloppement de génome, une séquence de promotion et une séquence eucariote d'ADNc commandée par la séquence de promotion. En rendant les séquences retrovirales de la construction insuffisantes en séquences de codage de protéines de revêtement, la construction devient incapable d'envelopper elle-même son genome comme un retrovirion. La séquence de promotion peut être une séquence se répétant à long terme. Alternativement, la séquence de promotion peut être un promoteur non-vital lié à la séquence d'ADNc, et promouvoir l'ADNc indépendamment de mécanismes cellulaires qui affectent l'expression de la séquence virale. Les génomes rétroviraux qui correspondent aux constructions sont récupérés comme virions complètement enveloppés par des virus vecteurs d'assistance qui codent leurs protéines de revêtement necéssaires pour envelopper les génomes correspondant aux constructions. Les virus vecteurs d'assistance auxquels manquent des séquences d'enveloppement n'enveloppent pas leurs propres génomes, et les cellules et constructions qui incorporent un tel virus vecteur déficient, produisent des rétrovirions qui ne sont capables d'infecter qu'une seule fois. Les virus vecteurs d'assistance qui produisent des protéines amphotropes enveloppent des rétrovirions de recombinaison qui sont infectieux pour des cellules de toute une variété d'espèces. Des cellules infectées par le rétrovirion de recombinaison sont transplantées dans un animal pour inclure une partie des cellules somatiques de l'animal et pour y exprimer le produit génétique de recombinaison. Les rétrovirions de recombinaison infecteront et changeront génétiquement les cellules somatiques d'un animal hôte, quand inoculées dans le fluide périphérique de l'animal.

column12: HEATING UNITS FOR HEATING ENCLOSURES AND METHODS OF HEATING ENCLOSURES
column13: A heating unit for heating an enclosure includes a base having a central axis, a first end, a second end axially opposite the first end, and a cavity extending axially from the first end. In addition, the heating unit includes a heater disposed in the cavity of the base. Further, the heating unit includes a heat sink mounted to the base. The heat sink includes a plurality of laterally spaced fins and a plurality of laterally spaced channels positioned between the plurality of fins. Still further, the heating unit includes a manifold coupled to the base. A surface of the manifold faces the base and the heat sink. The manifold includes a flow passage and a plurality of orifices in fluid communication with the flow passage. Each orifice has an outlet at the surface of the manifold that is aligned with one of the channels of the first heat sink.
column15: GARDNER ERIC JAMES;;BROWN CHRISTOPHER TODD;;EVANS GARY ARTHUR
EVANS KENNETH ARTHUR;;WILLS KEVIN JOHN;;EMERY ANTHONY ROLAND

column13: This invention relates to toothpaste containing an alumina hydrate abrasive and a source of fluoride. According to the invention, there is provided a toothpaste containing a source of fluoride ions and unmilled, precipitated alumina trihydrate as an abrasive, wherein the alumina trihydrate particles have a median particle size of at least 3 micrometres. The median particle size of the alumina trihydrate is preferably below 30 micrometres, more preferably from 5 to 20 micrometres, and most preferably 8 to 12 micrometres. It has been found that the use of an unmilled alumina trihydrate, obtained by precipitation, substantially reduces the loss of available fluoride on storage whereas the use of a milled alumina trihydrate causes significant loss of available fluoride.
column15: EVANS KENNETH ARTHUR;;WILLS KEVIN JOHN;;EMERY ANTHONY ROLAND

column12: LINEAR AUTOMATIC TRANSFER SWITCH AND SWITCHING MEANS
column13: A transfer switch including: a bus bar; a track parallel to the bus bar; a first power source connection proximate to the track; a second power source connection proximate to the track offset along the track from the first power source connection; a conductive core slidably coupled to the track, wherein the core includes a deformable array of conductive sections and the array includes contacting surfaces on opposite sides of the array; wherein the conductive core has a first position providing a conductive coupling between the bus bar and the first power source and a second position providing a conductive coupling between the bus bar and the second power source.

column12: SISTEMA PARA REFORZAR LA COBERTURA Y/O SERVICIO ENTRE EQUIPOS DE RADIOTELEFONIA.
column13: SISTEMA PARA REFORZAR LA COBERTURA Y/O SERVICIO ENTRE EQUIPOS DE RADIOTELEFONIA, QUE PERMITE DEVOLVER UN TRANSCEPTOR MOVIL A UN EMPLAZAMIENTO DIFERENTE DEL SISTEMA CELULAR DESDE EL EMPLAZAMIENTO ORIGINAL, QUE INCLUYE CIRCUITERIA PARA DETECTAR SEÑALES PROCEDENTES DEL TRANSCEPTOR MOVIL QUE SE TRANSMITEN EN UNA FRECUENCIA MODIFICADA, ASI COMO UNA CIRCUITERIA PARA TRASLADAR ESTAS SEÑALES DE NUEVO A SUS FRECUENCIAS ORIGINALMENTE ASIGNADAS SIN CAMBIAR LA POTENCIA DETECTADA DEL CAMPO DE LA SEÑAL, EN COMBINACION CON UNA CIRCUITERIA PARA ENVIAR LAS SEÑALES TRASLADADAS AL EMPLAZAMIENTO DIFERENTE DEL SISTEMA CELULAR PARA EVALUACION DE LIBERACION. EL METODO INCLUYE DETECTAR LAS SEÑALES RECIBIDAS; TRASLADAR LAS SEÑALES RECIBIDAS A UNA FRECUENCIA ORIGINALMENTE ASIGNADA EN BASE DE UN DESPLAZAMIENTO FIJO O DE OTRA INFORMACION PROPORCIONADA CONCERNIENTE AL TRASLADO JUNTO CON LA ETAPA DE ACTUALIZAR CONTINUAMENTE AQUELLAS FRECUENCIAS QUE SE TENGA QUE VOLVER A TRASLADAR.

column12: Measuring surface emissivity and temperature of a material using infrared imaging
column13: A method of measuring the surface emissivity and consequently the temperature of a first material 2 that is substantially transparent to infrared radiation. The first material 2 is temporarily or permanently mounted on a surface of a second material 7 of known emissivity. The infrared radiation emitted from the first material 2 is then measured using infrared imaging, and then the surface emissivity of the first material 2 is calculated using the measured infrared radiation emission, a spreading factor and the surface emissivity of the second material. The method is particularly suitable for measuring the surface emissivity and temperature of thin semiconductor devices.

column13: A device for hand launching a toy projectile in an upward direction primarily for the amusement of young people. The device includes; a striker and toy projectile fitted together by some suitable means, such as a sliding piston-in-cylinder, with an ordinary paper detonating cap placed in between; and, if desired, a handle on the striker. Striking the bottom of the striker on, or by, a hard surface inertially detonates the paper detonating cap, propelling the toy projectile from the striker.

column12: Method and system for estimating manufacturing costs
column13: A method and system estimates manufacturing costs for conventional and advanced materials and processes based on a process-oriented approach. A computer system comprises an input display for selecting one or more designs and one or more design parameters. Cost models are based upon process-oriented manufacturing cost estimates for a plurality of designs utilizing materials and manufacturing of processes. Software is programmed to receive selected designs and selected design parameters from the input display and pass the selected designs and design parameters to the cost models. An output display shows the manufacturing costs estimated by the cost models for the selected designs and design parameters. A manufacturing process flow simulation model highlights and quantifies the magnitude of the manufacturing process cost drivers.
column15: EVANS JERRY WILLIAM;;MEHTA PAUL P;;LUDWIG ARTHUR L
